<NOTANUSTUBH/> upajāti
<TEXT> anādimadhyāntam{ }anantapāraṁ</TEXT>   
<APP>\va <LEM>°ntam{ }ananta°</LEM> \msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; °ntam{ }anta° \msCbacorr</APP>
<APP>        <LEM>°pāraṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msM\Ed; °pāragaṁ \msNa\msNb\msNd</APP>
                        %pāragaṁ \msNd\msBod
        <PARAL>\va Łcf. Śivadharmottara 10.6: $
                ādimadhyāntanirmuktaḥ svabhāvavimalaḥ prabhuḥ |
                sarvajñaḥ paripūrṇaś ca śivo jñeyaḥ śivāgame ||</PARAL>

<TEXT> susūkṣmam{ }avyaktajagatsusāram|</TEXT>
<APP>\vb <LEM>susūkṣma°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; śusukṣma° \msCc</APP>
<APP><LEM>°jagatsusāram</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; °jagaśusāraṁ \msCc, °jagatsurāsuraṁ \msNb,                                                                                °jagatasusāram \msNd</APP>
        <!-- <TR> Having bowed to [Him] whose boundaries
        are limitless, who has no beginning, no middle part
        and no end, [to Him] who is very subtle and who
        is the unmanifest and fine essence of the world,
        [to Him] who is wholly complete with Hari, Indra, Brahmā
        and the other [gods], I shall recite [the work
        called] `A Compendium on the Essence of the Bull
        [of Dharma]'. </TR> -->

<TEXT> harīndrabrahmādibhir{ }āsamagraṁ</TEXT>
<APP>\vc <LEM>°bhir{ }āsamagraṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\Ed;                                                                °bhir{ }yat{ }samagraṁ \msM\ \unmetr</APP>
%%%%         \vc <LEM>°bhir{ }āptam{ }agraṁ</LEM> \conj; °bhir{ }āsamagraṁ \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\Ed, 
                                                                °bhir{ }yat{ }samagraṁ \msM\ \unmetr

%index_voc: āsamagra

<TEXT> praṇamya vakṣye vr̥ṣasārasaṁgraham||</TEXT> 1.1
        <APP>\vc <LEM>vr̥ṣa°</LEM> \msCapcorr\msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; °vr̥ṣo \msCaacorr</APP>
        <PARAL>ŁTestimonia for this chapter:    \msCa\ ff.\thinspace 193v--195v,
                                                \msCb\ ff.\thinspace 201v--203v,
                                                \msCc\ ff.\thinspace 267r--270r,
                                                \msNa\ ff.\thinspace 1v--3v,
                                                \msNb\ exp.\thinspace 44 (then exp.\thinspace
                                                        43 lower and then upper leaves; 1.62cd--2.22 are missing),
                                                \msNc\ ff.\thinspace 209v--211v,
                                                \msNd\ ff.\thinspace 227v--229v; 
                                                \msM\  ff.\thinspace 1r--3v;
                                                \mssCaCbCc\ = \msCa + \msCb + \msCc; 
                                                lemmata in parentheses indicate a longer chuck of text for
                                                which there may be additional variants given in the apparatus$</PARAL>
                        % pranamya \msCc
                        %Łpāragaṁ$ in \msNa\msNb: the same extra syllable as in pāda d.
<NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is reminiscent of, among other famous passages, Bhagavadgītā 11.19:

<sep/>
Łanādimadhyāntam anantavīryam <br/>
anantabāhuṁ śaśisūryanetram | <br/>
paśyāmi tvāṁ dīptahutāśavaktraṁ <br/>
svatejasā viśvam idaṁ tapantam ||$
<sep/>

This faint reference to the Bhagavadgītā seems proper at the
beginning of a work that claims to deliver a teaching 
based on, but also to surpass, the Mahābhārata (see following verses).
See also e.g. Kūrmapurāṇa 1.11.237:

<sep/>
        Łrūpaṁ tavāśeṣakalāvihīnam<br/>
        agocaraṁ nirmalam ekarūpam | <br/>
        anādimadhyāntam anantam ādyaṁ  <br/>
        namāmi satyaṁ tamasaḥ parastāt$ ||
<sep/>

To say that a god has no beginning and no
end in a temporal or spacial sense is natural
(Łanādi°...°antam$), but to have no `middle
part' (Ł°madhya°$) in these senses is slightly
less so.  Thus the rather commonly occuring
phrase Łanādimadhyāntam$ is probably 
a fixed expression usually referring to 
a formless, abstrace deity that is endless, eternal and immaterial.
As to which deity or what form of a deity this stanza 
refers to, it may be Śiva, his name not being
listed explicitely in pāda c,
but the phrasing of the verse is vague enough to
keep the question somewhat open: the impersonal
Brahman might be another option, even more so
if we look at 1.9--10, two verses nearby 
discussing Łbrahmavidyā$.
                
<sep/>
In Łpāda$ b Łjagat-susāraṁ$ is most probably not 
to be interpreted as Łjagatsu sāraṁ$ (`the essence in the worlds').

<sep/>
Strictly speaking, Łpāda$ c is unmetrical, but it is better to 
simply acknowledge here the phenomenon of `muta cum liquida', namely
that syllables followed by consonant clusters such as 
Łra, bra, hra, kra, śra, śya, śva, sva, dva$ can be treated as short.
(See Introduction CHECK)
Thus Łharīndrabrahmā°$ can be treated as a regular beginning
of an Łupajāti$ (. - . - -), the syllable 
Łbra$ not turning the previous syllable long.

<sep/>
The reading Łāsamagraṁ$ in Łpāda$ c is suspect,
although the initial Łā-$ might convey the meaning of
completeness (See e.g. Kale Higher Grammar, 126).
The fact that we could percieve
the ends of Łpāda$s a and b, as well as Łpāda$s c and
d, as rhyming pairs suggests that accepting the reading
Łāsamagram$ can be the right decision
(as suggested by Alessandro Battistini).
I translate this verse accordingly. \msM\ gives an exciting,
albeit unmetrical, alternative (Łyat samagraṁ$), but
this seems more like a guess to me than the correct reading.
For some time I was considering emending Łāsamagraṁ$.
The most tempting of all the possible options 
(Łarcyam/arhyam/arghyam/īḍyam/āḍhyam agraṁ, āsamastaṁ$) 
seemed to be Łāptam agraṁ$,
meaning `appointed/received/respected [by Hari, Indra,
Brahmā etc.] as the foremost one'. The fact that 
the Łakṣara$s Łāsam$ and Łāptam$ look similar in most
of the scripts used in our manuscripts could support this
conjecture. ŁĀptam$ could also
possibly refer to the text itself, although then the
syntax becomes slightly confusing: `I shall recite the
ŁVr̥ṣasārasaṁgraha$ that was first received by Hari...' etc.
Another candidate was Łāḍhyam agram$:
`Having bowed to [Him] who contains Hari, Indra, Brahmā
etc.' I have not emended the text because it is difficult
to know if any change is required and if yes, which reading 
to chose. There was no consensus when
this verse was discussed in our extended Śivadharma reading group.

<sep/>
Pāda d seems hypermetrical, but it can be interpreted as a Łvaṁśastha$
line, a change from Łtriṣṭubh$ to Łjagatī$ (as suggested by Dominic Goodall).  
</NOTE>

%index_biblio: Kūrmapurāṇa https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.292688/page/n175/mode/2up?view=theater

<SUBCHAPTER>janamejayavaiśampāyanasaṁvādaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> śatasāhasrikaṁ granthaṁ sahasrādhyāyam{ }uttamam|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Having listened to the Bhāratasaṁhitā [i.e. the Mahābhārata], the supreme book of 
              a hundred thousand [verses], a thousand chapters (Ładhyāya$)</TR> -->
<APP>\vb <LEM>sahasrādhyāyam{ }u°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM; sahaśradhyāyam{ }u° \msCc,                                                        sahasrādhyāyar{ }u° \Ed</APP>
                        % satasāhaśrikaṁ \msCc

<TEXT> parva cāsya śataṁ pūrṇaṁ śrutvā bhāratasaṁhitām||</TEXT> 1.2
        <!-- <TR>with all its hundred sections (Łparvan$),</TR> -->
<APP>\vc <LEM>parva cāsya</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr; parvañ{ }cāsya \msCb,parvam{ }asya \msCc\msNd\msMacorr\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>śataṁ pūrṇaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; ta \msCc</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>śrutvā</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; śraddhā \msCb</APP>
<APP><LEM>bhāratasaṁhitām</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; bhārasaṁhitā \msCc,                                         bhāratasaṁhitaṁ \msNd, nārādasaṁhitām \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vc Ł cf. MBh 1.2.70ab: $ etat{ }parvaśataṁ pūrṇaṁ vyāsenoktaṁ mahātmanā</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The dialogue of Janamejaya and Vaiśampāyana make up the outermost layer of the VSS 
                (except for the introductory stanzas 1.1-3), mostly containing
                general Łdharmaśāstric$ material.
                <sep/>
                The hundred Łparvan$s of the Mahābhārata are listed in MBh 1.2.33--70.</NOTE>

<TEXT> atr̥ptaḥ puna papraccha vaiśampāyanam{ }eva hi|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Janamejaya remained unsatisfied and what he asked Vaiśampāyana</TR> -->
<APP>\va <LEM>atr̥ptaḥ puna papraccha</LEM> \eme;a<UNCL>tr̥ptaḥ pu</UNCL>¤¤praccha \msCa,atr̥ptaḥ punaḥ papraccha \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc,atr̥ptaḥ punar{ }apracche \msCc,atr̥ptaḥ puna paḥpraccha \msNd,atr̥ptaḥ punaḥ papr̥ccha \msM,                atr̥ptā punaḥ papraccha \Ed</APP> 
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vaiśampāyana°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; vesampāyana° \msCc</APP>

                teachings, see Niśvāsa mūla 1.9:
                <sep/>
                <skt>vedāntaṁ viditaṁ deva sāṁkhyaṁ vai pañcaviṁśakam |
                     na ca tr̥ptiṁ gamiṣyāmo hy r̥te śaivād anugrahāt ||</skt>
                <sep/>
                 and Śivadharmaśāstra... CHECK.</NOTE>

<TEXT> janamejaya yat{ }pūrvaṁ tac{ }chr̥ṇu tvam{ }atandritaḥ||</TEXT> 1.3
        <!-- <TR>in the past, listen to that unweariedly.</TR> -->
<APP>\vc <LEM>janamejaya yat{ }pūrvaṁ</LEM> \eme;janamejayena yat{ }pūrvaṁ \msCapcorr\msCb\msNc\msNd\Ed,janamejaye yat{ }pūrvaṁ \msCaacorr,janmejayena yam{ }pūrvaṁ \msCc,janamejayena yat{ }pūrva \msNa,janamejayena yat{ }pūr<UNCL>va</UNCL> \msNb,                  janmejayeṇa yat{ }pūrvaṁ \msM</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>tac{ }chr̥ṇu tvam{ }a°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed;tac{ }chr̥ṇa tvam{ }a° \msCc, ×××××  \msNb, tac{ }chr̥ṇu svam{ }a° \msNd</APP>
<APP><LEM>°tandritaḥ</LEM> \msCc\msNa; °tandritam \msCa\msCb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed,                                                ××× \msNb</APP>
                        %\msCc chruṇa ... atandritaḥ CHECK
		<NOTE>Vaiśampāyana, a R̥ṣi, the disciple of Vyāsa, great-grandson to Arjuna,
		recited the Mahābhārata at the snake sacrifice of 
                Janamejaya. This setting is an echo of the starting point of the Mahābhārata, see MBh 1.1.8ff.
                In fact the next few verses in the VSS make it clear that we the VSS
                picks up where the Mahābhārata left off: Janamejaya has heard the whole Mahābhārata from
                Vaiśampāyana, but he is eager to hear more.
                <sep/>
                Note how we are forced to emend Łpāda$ c to contain a stem form proper noun (Łjanamejaya$)
                to maintain the metre, and note how the manuscripts struggle with this Łpāda$.
                Stem form nouns, Łprātipadika$s, abound in the VSS, see Introdcution p. XXCHECK.
        </NOTE>

<TEXT> dvaipāyanamukhodgīrṇaṁ dharmaṁ vā yad{ }dvijottama|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Teach me the Dharma that emerged from [Vyāsa] Dvaipāyana's mouth, O best of Brahmins.</TR> -->
<APP>\va <LEM>dvaipāyana°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\msM\Ed; dvepāyana° \msCc</APP>
<APP><LEM>°mukhodgīrṇaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; °mukhodgīrṇa \msCc, °mudgīrṇṇa \msNd,mukhaṁ gīrṇṇaṁ \msMacorr, mu<UNCL>khāṁ</UNCL> gīrṇṇaṁ \msMpcorr,                                                mukhād{ }gīrṇaṁ \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>dharmaṁ vā yad{ }dvi°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dharmaṁ yat{ }tad{ }dvi° \msCb,dharmavat{ }ya dvi° \msCc, dharma vā yad{ }dvi° \msNd,dharmavākyaṁ dvi° \msM</APP>
<APP>                  <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msNd\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msCc, °tamaḥ \msM</APP>  
        <NOTE>The majority of the MSS consulted include a Łvā$ in Łpāda$ b, 
                and although \msCb's reading seems a bit smoother, that manuscript rarely gives superior readings.
                Therefore I have chosen Łdharmaṁ vā yad$, in which Łvā$ is probably in a weak sense.
                That the secret Dharma Janamejaya is seeking is the one taught by Vyāsa Dvaipāyana,
                thus no real options are involved here, becomes clear in 1.6cd.
                The reading of \msM\ is tempting but could be a later correction.</NOTE>

<TEXT> kathayasva hi me tr̥ptiṁ kuru yatnāt{ }tapodhana||</TEXT> 1.5

<TEXT> śīlaśaucasamācāraṁ sarvabhūtadayāparam||</TEXT> 1.7
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°param</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; °nvitam \msCc\msNd, °<UNCL>pa</UNCL>raṁ \msNb</APP>
<!-- <TR>|F| Viṣṇu, the great Lord, assuming the form
         of a twice-born [Brahmin], wanted to
         test the one (i.e. Anarthayajña) who performed
         nonmaterial sacrifices (i.e. Łanarthayajña$),
         the one who focused on his austerities and
         observances, the one whose conduct was virtuous
         and pure, and who was intent on compassion towards
         all living beings, and therefore he (Viṣṇu)
         humbly asked him a question.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the odd syntax here: Łviṣṇunā... dvijarūpadharo bhūtvā papraccha$.
               The agent of the active verb is in the instrumental case.
                <sep/>
               On Anarthayajña, the interlocutor of VSS 1.9--10.2 and 19.1--21.22, and
               an important figure discussed in 22.3ff, as well as a concept (`nonmaterial sacrifice'),
               see Kiss 2022 and Introduction XXCHECK.</NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>kālapāśaḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The noose of death and time</TRSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <APP>\vo <LEM>°rāga uvāca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °rāgovāca \msNd</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR> -->

        % CHECK śmaśāna rules, who ... Kane v4 p189ff and p222, but especially 227ff !
<TEXT> dehī dehe kṣayaṁ yāte bhūjalāgniśivādibhiḥ|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>When the body disintegrates in the ground, in water, in fire or [is torn apart] by jackals 
                        and other [animals],</TR> -->
<APP>\va <LEM>dehe kṣa°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNc; dehāt{ }kṣa° \msCb, dehakṣa° \msNa\msNb\msNd\msM\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>yāte</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; yānte \msNd</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°gniśivādibhiḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °gniśivādibhi \msCc, °gniṁ śi*dibhi \msNd</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Łcf.\ Kūrmapurāṇa 2.23.74: $ 
                atha kaścit{ }pramādena mriyate 'gniviṣādibhiḥ| 
                tasyāśaucaṁ vidhātavyaṁ kāryaṁ caivodakādikam||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>The word Ł°śivā°$ in Łpāda$ b is slightly suspect, and could be the result
                of metathesis, from Ł°viṣā°$ (`by poison'). Nevertheless, 
                jackals seems appropriate in this context, for they 
                are commonly associated with human corpses, death and the cremation ground
                (see e.g. Ohnuma 2019). 
                (Reiko Ohnuma 2019 = Ohnuma, R. The Heretical, Heterodox Howl: 
                        Jackals in Pāli Buddhist Literature. Religions 2019, 10, 221.)</NOTE>

%index_biblio: Kūrmapurāṇa
%index_biblio: Ohnuma 2019: Reiko Ohnuma. The Heretical, Heterodox Howl: Jackals in Pāli Buddhist Literature. Religions 2019, 10, 221.

<TEXT> kālapāśaiḥ kathaṁ baddho nirdehaś{ }ca kathaṁ vrajet|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>°pāśaiḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; °pāśe \msCc, °pāśai \msNd</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>baddho</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM\Ed; ba<UNCL>ddho</UNCL> \msCb, baddha \msNd</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>nirdehaś{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMpcorr\Ed; nirdahaḥ sa \msCc, nirdehasya \msNd,nirdehan{ }ma \msMacorr</APP>

        <!-- <TR>How is it bound by the nooses of death/time? And if it is bodiless, how can it move?</TR> -->

                        is both Yama's noose, and also the limitation caused by time, 
                        as becomes clear at the discussion on the different time units in verses 1.11--31.</NOTE>

<APP>\vc <LEM>parārdhaṁ ca</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; <UNCL>pa</UNCL>rārddhaṁ ca \msCa,parādhañ{ }ca \msMacorr, parārdhaṁñ{ }ce \msMpcorr</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>paraṁ caiva</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; parāñ{ }caiva \msM</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>vaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msMacorr; naḥ \msMpcorr, yaḥ \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°dīpitam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dīyatāṁ \msM</APP>
% \msM is weird with its naḥ, not to mention pratidīyatāṁ
        <!-- <TR>as well as Łparārdha$ and Łpara$. You have made these things appear as
                             exciting, as things to hear.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The reading of all manuscripts consulted, Łvinisr̥tam$, 
                may be considered metrical if we interpret it, loosely, as Łvinisritam$.
        <sep/>
		ŁPāda$ d is suspicious and my translation is tentative.
		\msM s reading in pāda d (£srotuṁ naḥ pratidīyatāṁ$) might make sense 
		("give it back/repeat it for us again"), but it sounds forced,
		as if the scribe tried to come up with a reading that he understood
		better than £srotuṁ vaḥ pratidīpitam$, which is in fact not easy to interpret.</NOTE>

                         a hundred quadrillion (Łparārdha$), and two hundred quadrillion (Łpara$).</TR> -->

	               may be a result of an eyeskip to 1.35c.</NOTE>

        <APP>\vc <LEM>purākhyāto</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; purākhyātaṁ \msM, mamākhyāto \Ed</APP>
% accept \msM?
        <!-- <TR>in the manner in which Brahmā taught Mātariśvan in the past, truthfully.</TR> -->
        <PARAL>\vcd Łcf. Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 3.4.58cd: $ 
                        brahmā dadau śāstram{ }idaṁ purāṇaṁ mātariśvane</PARAL> 
        <NOTE>Note that in Łpāda$ d Łmātariśvan$ stands for the accusative Łmātariśvānaṁ$ or
                        the dative Łmātariśvane$ or the genitive Łmātariśvanaḥ$.
                        The claim that Brahmā taught Mātariśvan is confirmed in 1.64cd,
                        again using the nominative for the accusative, dative or genitive, and
                        also e.g. in Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 3.4.58cd (see the apparatus).</NOTE>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>pūrvataḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>East</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> sahāsahaḥ sahaḥ sahyo visahaḥ saṁhato 'sahā|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>sahāsahaḥ</LEM> \msNc; sāhāsaha \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msM\Ed</APP>
<APP><LEM>sahaḥ sahyo</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;		      sahaḥ sajñā \msCb, saho sahyaḥ \msM, sahaḥ sajño \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>visahaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; visaha \msCc\msM</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>sahā</LEM> \msM; sabhā \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, sabhāḥ \msCb, satā \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[1] Saha, [2] Asaha, [3] Sahas, [4] Sahya, [5] Visaha, [6] Saṁhata, [7] Asahā,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I chose to supply an Łavagraha$ before Łsahā$ only because all the sources 
                consulted read Łsaṁhato$ as the previous word, making the Łsandhi$
                Ło-s$ suspicious. 
                Note that many of the names here and in the following verses are,
                in the absence of any parallel passage, rather insecure.
                What is clear here is that the names evoke the name Sahasrākṣa,
                one of the appellations of
                Indra, the guadrian of the eastern direction.</NOTE>

<TEXT> prasaho 'prasahaḥ sānuḥ pūrvato daśa nāyakāḥ||</TEXT> 1.41

        <APP>\vd <LEM>pūrvato</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msM; parvato \Ed</APP>

<APP>\vb <LEM>yaniyugmā yano yanaḥ</LEM> \msNb; yaniyugmā nayo yanaḥ \msCa\msCc\msNa,yaniyugmā nayo nayaḥ \msCb,	yaniyugmā nayo yamaḥ \msNc, daśamā yāmyam{ }āśr̥tā \msM, yaniyugmā nayonaya \Ed</APP>

                        the name Łsaṁyama$, and the variant Łyanoyanaḥ$ because I suspect that
                        most of the names here should begin with Łya$. All the name forms
                        in this verse are to be taken as tentative. The only 
                        guiding light is the presence of Łya$, reinforcing a connection with Yama.</NOTE>

        The body of the Egg is like that of the full moon at moonrise.</TR> -->

<SUBCHAPTER>vyāsāḥ</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The Redactors (of the Purāṇas)</TRSUBCHAPTER>
% purāṇāni? or aśī for aśīti 80?
% stem form?
<TEXT> purāṇāśīsahasrāṇi śatāni dvijasattama|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>O truest of the twice-born, the Purāṇa[s of] 8,000,000 [verses]</TR> -->
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°sattama</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msM\Ed; ××maḥ  \msCc</APP>
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a should probably be analysed and interpreted as 
                        Łpurāṇam (purāṇānām aśītisahasrāṇi śatāni ślokāni) brahmaṇā kathitam$.
                        Alternatively, pāda a may have originally read Łpurāṇāni sahasrāṇi$,
                        and then the inital number of verses transmitted by Brahmā is
                        a hundred thousand.
                <sep/>
                Compare this list to Viṣṇupurāṇa 3.3.11--19:
                <sep/>
                Łdvāpare prathame vyastaḥ svayaṁ vedaḥ svayaṁbhuvā|<br/>
                dvitīye dvāpare caiva vedavyāsaḥ prajāpati||<br/>
                tr̥tīye cośanā vyāsaś caturthe ca br̥haspatiḥ| <br/>
                savitā pañcame vyāsaḥ ṣaṣṭhe mr̥tyuḥ smr̥taḥ prabhuḥ|| <br/>
                saptame ca tathaivendro vasiṣṭhaś cāṣṭame smr̥taḥ| <br/>
                sārasvataś ca navame tridhāmā daśame smr̥taḥ|| <br/>
                ekādaśe tu triśikho bharadvājas tataḥ paraḥ| <br/>
                trayodaśe cāntarikṣo varṇī cāpi caturdaśe|| <br/>
                trayyāruṇaḥ pañcadaśe ṣoḍaśe tu dhanañjayaḥ| <br/>
                kratuñjayaḥ saptadaśe tadūrdhvaṁ ca jayaḥ smr̥taḥ|| <br/>
                tato vyāso bharadvājo bharadvājāc ca gautamaḥ| <br/>
                gautamād uttaro vyāso haryātmā yo 'bhidhīyate|| <br/>
                atha haryātmanonte ca smr̥to vājaśravāmuniḥ| <br/>
                somaśuṣkāyaṇas tasmāt tr̥ṇabindur iti smr̥taḥ|| <br/>
                r̥kṣobhūdbhārgavas tasmād vālmīkir yo 'bhidhīyate| <br/>
                tasmād asmatpitā śaktir vyāsas tasmād ahaṁ mune|| <br/>
                jātukarṇo 'bhavan mattaḥ kr̥ṣṇadvaipāyanas tataḥ| <br/>
                aṣṭaviṁśatir ity ete vedavyāsāḥ purātanāḥ||  <br/>$
                <sep/>
                Another relevant passage is Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 3.4.58cd--67:
                <sep/>
                Łbrahmā dadau śāstram idaṁ purāṇaṁ mātariśvane|| <br/>
                tasmāc cośanasā prāptaṁ tasmāc cāpi br̥haspatiḥ|   <br/>
                br̥haspatis tu provāca savitre tadanantaram||   <br/>
                savitā mr̥tyave prāha mr̥tyuś cendrāya vai punaḥ| <br/>
                indraś cāpi vasiṣṭāya so 'pi sārasvatāya cai|| <br/>
                sārasvatas tridhāmne 'tha tridhāmā ca śaradvate| <br/>
                śaradvāṁs tu triviṣṭāya so 'ntarikṣāya dattavān|| <br/>
                carṣiṇe cāntarikṣo vai so 'pi trayyāruṇāya ca| <br/>
                trayyāruṇād dhanañjayaḥ sa vai prādāt kr̥tañjaye|| <br/>
                kr̥tañjayāt tr̥ṇañjayo bharadvājāya so 'py atha|   <br/>
                gautamāya bharadvājaḥ so 'pi niryyantare punaḥ|| <br/>
                niryyantaras tu provāca tathā vājaśravāya vai|   <br/>
                sa dadau somaśuṣmāya sa cādāt tr̥ṇabindave|| <br/>
                tr̥ṇabindus tu dakṣāya dakṣaḥ provāca śaktaye| <br/>
                śakteḥ parāśaraś cāpi garbhasthaḥ śrutavānidam|| <br/>
                parāśarāj jātukarṇyas tasmād dvaipāyanaḥ prabhuḥ|   <br/>
                dvaipāyanāt punaś cāpi mayā prāptaṁ dvijottama|| <br/>
                mayā caitat punaḥ proktaṁ putrāyāmitabuddhaye|   <br/>
                ity eva vākyaṁ brahmādiguruṇāṁ samudāhr̥tam||  $ <br/>
                </NOTE>

<TEXT> <COLOPHON>iti vr̥ṣasārasaṁgrahe brahmāṇḍasaṁkhyā nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ</COLOPHON></TEXT>
        <TRCOLOPHON>Here ends the first chapter in the Vr̥ṣasārasaṁgraha called the Enumeration of the Brahmāṇḍa[s].</TRCOLOPHON> 
<APP> Ł \Colo: $ <LEM>nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; nāmādhyāyaḥ prathamaḥ śloka 77 \msM,                                nāma prathamo 'dhyāya \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Manuscripts \msCc\ and \msM\ place the Łiti$ of the colophon at the end of the last śloka, before
                the daṇḍas, thus: Łicchasīti ||@||$ (\msCc) and Łicchasi iti ||o||$ (\msM).
                Note also that \msM\ gives the number of ślokas in this chapter, 77, which is exactly
                the number of verses this critical edition has produced. The scribe of \msM\ struggled 
                with eyeskips in this chapter, therefore it seems unlikely that he himself
                counted the number of verses he had copied and arrived at this very figure.
                Rather, he copied the number from his exemplar.</NOTE>

<TEXT> bhogam{ }akṣayas{ }tatraiva janmamr̥tyur{ }na vidyate||</TEXT> 2.25
        <APP>\vc <LEM>bhogam{ }akṣayas{ }ta°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; bhogamayās{ }tu ta° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°mr̥tyur{ }na</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °mr̥tyu na \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>I do not know the length and width of the Śivāṇḍa.
             Enjoyment is undecaying there, and there is no birth or death there.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Pāda c is unmetrical, or rather, a ra-vipulā with licence 
                (tatraiva as SHORT-LONG). Note also the gender problem 
                (Łbhogam akṣayas$), or rather take Ł-m-$ as a sandhi-bridge 
                (Łbhoga-m-akṣayas$, for Łbhogo 'kṣayas$).</NOTE>

<TEXT> kimarthaṁ dharmam{ }ity{ }āhuḥ katimūrtiś{ }ca kīrtyate|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>āhuḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; āhu \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Why do they call [Dharma] Dharma? And how many embodiments (Łmūrti$) is he known to have?</TR> -->
% NEW
        <NOTE>For the correct interpretation of Łpāda$ a, namely to decide whether these questions
                focus on the bull of Dharma or Dharma itself/himself, see 
                the end of the previous chapter, where Łdharma$ was mentioned (2.40b),
                and to which the present verse is a reaction; and also
                MBh 12.110.10--11:
                <sep/>
                Łprabhāvārthāya bhūtānāṁ dharmapravacanaṁ kr̥tam|<br/>
                 yat syād ahiṁsāsaṁyuktaṁ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ||<br/>
                 dhāraṇād dharma ity āhur dharmeṇa vidhr̥tāḥ prajāḥ|<br/>
                 yat syād dhāraṇasaṁyuktaṁ sa dharma iti niścayaḥ||$
                <sep/>
                Note the similarities with this chapter: the phrase Łdharma ity āhur$,
                the fact that the present chapter from verse 18 on is actually a chapter on Łahiṁsā$,
                and that the etimological explanation involves the word [Łā$]Łdhāraṇa$ in
                both cases. These lead me to think that in Łpāda$s ab of this verse in the VSS,
                it is Dharma that is the focus of the inquiry and not the bull.</NOTE>

                 It is called Dharma because it supports (ŁāDHĀRaṇa$) and because it is great (ŁMAhattva$).</TR> -->
        <PARAL>\vo\ \kb\ ŁMatsyapurāṇa 145.27: $  dharmeti dhāraṇe dhātur{ }mahatve caiva ucyate|

                        Łbhaja ity eṣa dhātur vai sevāyāṁ parikīrtitaḥ$; etc.</NOTE>

<APP>\vab <LEM>°smr̥tidvayor{ }mūrtiś{ }ca°</LEM> \msCa; °smr̥tidvayo mūrttiś{ }ca° \msCb\msNb, °smr̥tidvayo mūrtti ca° \msNa\msNc,                                                                        °smr̥tir{ }dvayo mūrtiś{ }ca \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> caturāśrama yo dharmaḥ kīrtitāni manīṣibhiḥ||</TEXT> 3.4
        <APP>\vc <LEM>caturā°</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; cāturā° \msCa\msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The four-legged Bull is the embodiment of both Śruti and Smr̥ti.
               The four Łāśrama$s are taught by the wise to be [the four legs of] Dharma.
                [or rather: ... which is Dharma as made up of the four āśramas... kīrtitaḥ!]</TR> -->
% only 3 āśramas here ! Judit ; CsK: maybe taṁ santo... is the fourth? NEW
% Olivelle Āśrama p55: "Elsewhere also in the same dialogue the author affirms "the unity of all the āśramas with
respect to their end" (12.262.34) and calls the āśramas the four feet of dharma (12.262.19,21)."
        ŚDh-Umāmaheśvarasaṁvāda 10.61–36 dealing with dharma as the bull whose four legs represent the four yugas.
        <NOTE>A similar image of the legs of the Bull of Dharma being the four Łāśrama$s 
                is hinted at MBh 12.262.19--21: 
                <sep/>
                    Łdharmam{ }ekaṁ catuṣpādam{ }āśritās{ }te nararṣabhāḥ|
               <br/>taṁ santo vidhivat{ }prāpya gacchanti paramāṁ gatim||
               <br/>gr̥hebhya eva niṣkramya vanam{ }anye samāśritāḥ|
               <br/>gr̥ham{ }evābhisaṁśritya tato 'nye brahmacāriṇaḥ||
               <br/>dharmam{ }etaṁ catuṣpādam{ }āśramaṁ brāhmaṇā viduḥ|
               <br/>ānantyaṁ brahmaṇaḥ sthānaṁ brāhmaṇā nāma niścayaḥ||$
        <sep/>
        On the more frequently quoted interpretation of the four legs, see Olivelle `Āśrama', 235:
        ``Dharma and truth possess all four feet and are whole during the Kr̥ta yuga, 
        and people did not obtain anything unrighteously (Ładharmeṇa$). 
        By obtaining, however, Łdharma$ has lost one foot during each of the other Łyuga$s 
        and righteousness (Łdharma$) likewise has diminished by one quarter due to theft, 
        falsehood, and deceit. (MDh 1.81--82)''
        <sep/>
        Understand Łpāda$s c and d as Łcatvāri āśramāṇi kīrtitāni dharmo manīṣibhiḥ$ or
                Łyo dharmaḥ kīrtitaś caturāśramāṇi manīṣibhiḥ$ or 
                Łyo dharmaś caturāśramaḥ kīrtito manīṣibhiḥ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> devamānuṣatiryaṁ ca narakasthāvarādayaḥ||</TEXT> 3.5
        <!-- <TR>And the paths of Dharma are five. Listen, O Brahmin:
                  [existence as] gods, men, animals, [existence in] hell 
                        and [as] immovable things [such as plants and rocks] etc.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Łgatiś$ as Łgatayaś$ and note that Łvijñeyāḥ$ is an emendation from
                Łvijñeyaḥ$ following the logic of 3.1d. 
                Łtirya$ seems to be an acceptable nominal stem in this text for Łtiryañc$. See
                e.g. 4.6a: Łdevamānuṣatiryeṣu$.  Ł°ādayaḥ$ in Łpāda$ d seems superfluous.</NOTE>

<TEXT> brahmaṇo hr̥dayaṁ bhittvā jāto dharmaḥ sanātanaḥ|</TEXT>

<TEXT> tasya patnī mahābhāgā trayodaśa sumadhyamāḥ||</TEXT> 3.6
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°madhyamāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; \om\ \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Eternal Dharma was born after splitting Brahmā's heart.
                 He has beautiful wives, thirteen in number, with nice waists.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the use of the singular in Łpāda$s c and d. I have left Łsumadhyamāḥ$ as the
        manuscripts transmit it: it signals the presence of the plural. And consider 
        correcting Łmahābhāgā$ to Łmahābhāgās$. In sum, 
                understand Łtasya patnyo mahābhāgās trayodaśa sumadhyamāḥ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> eṣa dharmanisargo 'yaṁ kiṁ bhūyaḥ śrotum{ }icchasi||</TEXT> 3.7
        <!-- <TR>This is the emergence of Dharma. What more do you wish to hear?</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Again, I have chosen/applied the plural forms Ł°ādyāḥ$ and Łsumanoharāḥ$ in Łpāda$ b to hint at the fact
                        that the presence of the plural is to be preferred here; thus only Łviśālākṣī$ is 
                        problematic. As Łpatnī$ in the previous verse, it should be treated as a plural.
        Note the use of the singular for the plural also in Łpāda$s cd, especially Łbabhūva ha$ for Łbabhūvuḥ$. 
        <sep/>
        MMW on Dakṣa:
        ``daughters of whom 27 become the Moon's wives, forming the lunar asterisms, and 13 
        [or 17 BhP.; or 8 R.] those of Kaśyapa, becoming by this latter the mothers 
        of gods, demons, men, and animals, while 10 are married to Dharma, Mn. ix, 128f.'' CHECK</NOTE>

        </NOTE>

<TEXT> buddhiḥ śāntir{ }vapuḥ kīrtiḥ siddhiḥ prasūtisambhavāḥ||</TEXT> 3.9
        <APP>\vc <LEM>buddhiḥ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; buddhi \msCa</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>siddhiḥ prasūtisambhavāḥ</LEM> \conj; siddhiś{ }cābhūtisambhavā \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc,                                        siddhiś{ }cātisambhavā \msCb, siddhiś{ }ca bhūtisambhavā \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[Dharma's wives are:] [1] Śraddhā (`Faith'), [2] Lakṣmī (`Prosperity'), [3] Dhr̥ti (`Resolution'), 
        [4] Tuṣṭi (`Satisfaction'), [5] Puṣṭi (`Growth'), [6] Medhā (`Wisdom'), 
        [7] Kriyā (`Ritual'), [8] Lajjā (`Modesty'), [9] Buddhi (`Intelligence'), 
        [10] Śānti (`Tranquillity'), [11] Vapus (`Beauty'), [12] Kīrti (`Fame'), [13] Siddhi (`Success'), 
                      [all] born to Prasūti [Dakṣa's wife].</TR> -->
        <NOTE><sep/>Łprasūtisambhavāḥ$ is a rather bold conjecture that can be supported by two facts:
                        firstly, the readings of the manuscripts are difficult to make sense of and thus are
                                         probably corrupt; secondly, a corruption from the name Prasūti, that of Dakṣa's wife, to Łābhūti$
                                         is relatively easily to explain, Łsū$ and Łbhū$ being close enough in some scripts 
                                         (e.g. in \msCa) to cause confusion. Another option would be to accept 
                                         Ābhūti as the name of Dakṣa's wife.
                <sep/>
                For Prasūti being Dakṣa's wife in other sources,
                         see e.g. Liṅgapurāṇa 1.5.20--21 (but also note the presence of the name Sambhūti...):
                               Łprasūtiḥ suṣuve dakṣāc{ }caturviṁśatikanyakāḥ|
                                śraddhāṁ lakṣmīṁ dhr̥tiṁ puṣṭiṁ tuṣṭiṁ medhāṁ kriyāṁ tathā||
                                buddhi lajjāṁ vapuḥ śāntiṁ siddhiṁ kīrtiṁ mahātapāḥ|
                                khyātiṁ śāntiś{ }ca saṁbhūtiṁ smr̥tiṁ prītiṁ kṣamāṁ tathā||$</NOTE>

<TEXT> kriyāyās{ }tv{ }abhayaḥ putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca||</TEXT> 3.11
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tv{ }abhayaḥ putro</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; tūbhayaḥ putrau \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>daṇḍaḥ</LEM> \corr; daṇḍe \msCa\msNaacorr, daṇḍo \msCb, daṇḍa° \msNapcorr\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; tu \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Kriyā's sons are Abhaya (`Freedom from danger'), Daṇḍa (`Punishment') and Samaya (`Law').</TR> -->
        <NOTE>It is tempting to emend Łabhayaḥ$ to Łubhayaḥ$, thus matching the relevant line in the Kūrmapurāṇa cited above:
                        Łkriyāyāś cābhavat putro daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$ and allotting only two sons to Kriyā, but
                        in a number of sources Kriyā actually has three sons, see e.g. Viṣṇupurāṇa 1.7.29(ab? CHECK in book),
                        where they are named as Daṇḍa, Naya and Vinaya:
                                Łmedhā śrutaṁ kriyā daṇḍaṁ nayaṁ vinayam eva ca$. 
                        Perhaps read Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ putro$ in pāda c? Compare Vāyupurāṇa 1.10.34cd
                                        Łkriyāyās tu nayaḥ prokto daṇḍaḥ samaya eva ca$ 
                                with Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 1.9.60ab:
                                        Łkriyāyās tanayau proktau damaś ca śama eva ca$</NOTE>

                 Lajjā has only one son, Vinaya. In the above verse (VSS 3.12), Łsudhiyaḥ$ (for Łsudhīḥ$) may only be 
                        qualifying Łapramāda$, thus Lajjā may have two sons: Vinaya and the wise Apramāda.</NOTE>

<TEXT> kautūhalam{ }atīvaṁ me kartaya jñānasaṁśayam||</TEXT> 3.14
<APP>\vc <LEM>kautūhala°</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; kotūhala° \msCb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°tīvaṁ me</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tīva me \msCb</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>kartaya</LEM> \eme; kīrtaya \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°saṁśayam</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc\Ed; °saṁśayaḥ \msCb\msNb</APP>
                <!-- <TR>I am extremely intrigued. Cut my doubts concerning [this] knowledge.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun and the form Łatīvaṁ$ for Łatīva$ metri causa. 
        My emendation from Łkīrtaya$ (`declare') to Łkartaya$ (`cut') was influenced by the combination
        of Łchindhi$ and Łsaṁśaya$, often with Łkautūhala$, elsewhere in the VSS:
                3.2b: Łsaṁśayaṁ chindhi tattvataḥ$; 
                10.XXcd: Łkautūhalaṁ mahaj jātaṁ chindhi saṁśayakārakam$;
                15.2ab: Łetat kautūhalaṁ chindhi saṁśayaṁ parameśvara$. 
                The reading Łkīrtaya$ may have been the result of the influence of Łkīrtitā$ in 3.13b above 
                       (De Simini's convinicing observation).</NOTE>

laukikaṁ sampravakṣyāmi yena svargam vrajanti te |

        <!-- <TR>[Others,] tie up [people] at their feet and their arms and chests.
                [These,] bound by [with?] their hair and [on their?] necks,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Łbhujoraś ca$ in Łpāda$ a as Łbhuje urasi ca$, in this case with an instance of double sandhi:
                Łbhuje urasi ca$ -- Łbhuja urasi ca$ -- Łbhujorasi ca$. Alternatively, understand it as a compound:     
                                Łbhujorasi$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> viṣavahniśaraśastrair{ }māyāyogabalena vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>°śastrair{ }māyā°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb; °śastrai mā° \msNc, °śastrair{ }mmayā° \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> hiṁsakāny{ }āhu viprendra munayas{ }tattvadarśinaḥ||</TEXT> 3.23
<APP>\vc <LEM>hiṁsakāny{ }āhu vi°</LEM> \msCb\msNb\msNc;                                hiṁsakāny{ }āhur{ }vi° \msCa\msNa\ \unmetr, hiṁsakety{ }āhu vi° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>are called murderers by the sages who see the truth, O great Brahmin[, and 
                to be killed by the same methods].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ a is unmetrical.
               Note how elliptical this verse is and that Łhiṁsakāni$ is neuter although it refers to 
                people, perhaps implying Łbhūtāni$. Alternatively, take Ł°ny°$ in Łhiṁsakāny$ as 
                rather unusual sandhi-bridge (Łhiṁsakā-ny-āhu$). 
                Note also that Łāhu$ stands for Łāhur$ metri causa.</NOTE>

        <!-- <TR>Non-violence is the highest Dharma. He who abandons it is a wicked person.</TR> -->

%folioinfo \msCa\ 391.jpg
<TEXT> kleśāyāsavinirmuktaṁ sarvadharmaphalapradam||</TEXT> 3.24
        <!-- <TR>It is free of pain and trouble, it yields the fruits of all [other] Dharmic teachings [in itself].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note Łdharma$ as a neuter noun in Łpāda$ a and that Ł°vinirmuktaṁ$ and
                        Ł°pradam$ are neuter accordingly.</NOTE>

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataro mūrkho nātaḥ parataraṁ tamaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°taraṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCbpcorr\msNa\msNb\msNc; °tan \msCbacorr\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>There isn't a bigger fool than he [who abandons it is]. There is no bigger mental darkness
                                [than the abandonment of non-violence].</TR> -->

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataraṁ duḥkhaṁ nātaḥ parataro 'yaśaḥ||</TEXT> 3.25
        <!-- <TR>There is no greater suffering or greater infamy.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note that Łparataro$ is masculine in Łpāda$ d, picking up a neuter Ł'yaśaḥ$.
        This phenomenon is probably the result of Ł'yaśaḥ$ resembling a masculine noun ending in Ł-aḥ$
                and also of the metrical problem with the grammatically correct
                        Łnātaḥ parataram ayaśaḥ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> nātaḥ parataraṁ pāpaṁ nātaḥ parataraṁ viṣam|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>There is no greater sin or a more effective poison.</TR> -->

<TEXT> nātaḥ paratarāvidyā nātaḥ paraṁ tapodhana||</TEXT> 3.26
        <APP>\vd <LEM>paraṁ tapodhana</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; para tapodyamāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>There is no greater ignorance, there is nothing worse, O great ascetic.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ d (Łnātaḥ paraṁ tapodhana$) is slightly suspicious. 
                The vocative Łtapodhana$ usually refers to Anarthayajña in these
                passages, and not to Vigatarāga, as here.  The text may have read Łnātaḥ paratamo 'dhanaḥ$ 
                (`There is no bigger loss of wealth') or possibly something starting with
                Łnātaḥ paraṁ tapo ...$ (`There is no greater austerity...').</NOTE>

        <APP>\vc <LEM>guṇākarṣā°</LEM> \conjTorzsok; guṇākāśā° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, guṇā kuryā° \Ed</APP>
       <!-- <TR> in order to be able to draw a bow with force,
                        or out of fear of the danger coming from the enemy.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Łguṇākāśāt$ in pāda c is difficult to interpret and 
                Łguṇākarṣāt$ is a conjecture by Judit Törzsök which fits the context well,
                although the polysemy of Łguṇa$ may allow for other solutions.
        <sep/>
        Verses 3.40--42 may be echoing Brahmapurāṇa 216.64--66:
        <sep/>
                      Ł māṁsān miṣṭataraṁ nāsti bhakṣyabhojyādikeṣu ca |<br/>
                        tasmān māṁsaṁ na bhuñjīta nāsti miṣṭaiḥ sukhodayaḥ || <br/>

        </NOTE>

<APP>\vc <LEM>°koṭi°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °koṭī° \Ed\ \unmetr</APP>

%      - -     -  .  . -?   . -  . . . -    -  - .  -  -  . -
% unmetrical
<TEXT> etatpuṇyaphalam{ }ahiṁsakajanaḥ prāpnoti niḥsaṁśayaḥ||</TEXT> 3.42
<APP>\vd <LEM>°phalam{ }ahiṁsa°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °phalaṁ tv{ }ahiṁsa° \msNc</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>niḥsaṁśayaḥ</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ¤¤¤¤ \msCa, niḥsaṁśaya¤ \msCb, niḥsaṁśayaṁ \Ed</APP>
        % nissaṁśayaḥ \msCc, niḥsaṁśayaḥ \msNa
        <!-- <TR>A person who refrains from violence will gain,
                 no doubt about it, the [same] meritorious rewards
                 that others would get by donating the three worlds filled with jewels and 
                 gems in their entirety to an excellent Brahmin,
                 by performing a thousand [times] ten trillion (Łpadma$)
                 [times] ten thousand (Łayuta$) Łkoṭīyajña$ (= koṭihoma?) sacrifices,
                 by donating the earth [to a priest] as sacrificial fee,
                 and by bathing [at] a thousand times ten million times a million (Łniyuta$) 
                                                sacred places at once,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>On Łpadma$ meaning `ten trillion', and on other words for numbers, see 1.32--35. 
        <sep/>
                Łkoṭīyajña$ in pāda d may refer to a special kind of sacrifice, 
                mostly known as Łkoṭihoma$ in the Purāṇas and in inscriptions 
                (see e.g. Fleming 2010 and 2013)
                It probably involves a hundred fire-pits 
                and a hundred times one thousand brāhmaṇas (hence the name `the ten-million sacrifice').
                See e.g. Bhaviṣyapurāṇa uttaraparvan 4.142.54--58:
                        <sep/>
                             Ł  śatānano daśamukho dvimukhaikamukhas tathā |
                                caturvidho mahārāja koṭihomo vidhīyate || 
                                kāryasya gurutāṁ jñātvā naiva kuryād aparvaṇi |
                                yathā saṁkṣepataḥ kāryaḥ koṭihomas tathā śr̥ṇu ||
                                kr̥tvā kuṇḍaśataṁ divyaṁ yathoktaṁ hastasaṁmitam |
                                ekaikasmiṁs tataḥ kuṇḍe śataṁ viprān niyojayet ||
                                sadyaḥ pakṣe tu viprāṇāṁ sahasraṁ parikīrtitam |
                                ekasthānapraṇīte 'gnau sarvataḥ paribhāvite || 
                                homaṁ kuryur dvijāḥ sarve kuṇḍe kuṇḍe yathoditam |
                                yathā kuṇḍabahutve 'pi rājasūye mahākratau ||  $
                        <sep/>
                Note that the second syllable of Łphalam$ in Łpāda$ d is treated as a long syllable: this
                happens often at word-boundaries in this text; and 
                note how \msNc\ aims to restore the metre by inserting Łtv$ after its Łphalaṁ$.</NOTE>

Fleming, Benjamin J. `New copperplate grant of Śrīcandra (no. 8) from
Bangladesh' BSOAS Volume 73, Issue 02 (June 2010, pp. 223--244)).
Peter Bisschop studied the kotihoma !
                        
Fleming, Benjamin J. `Making Land Sacred: Inscriptional Evidence for Buddhist Kings and Brahman Priests in Medieval Bengal' Numen 60.5-6 (2013) 559–85.

<TEXT> tiṣṭhanti sāgarāḥ satye samayena priyavrataḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>sāgarāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; sāgarā \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>samayena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; satyena ca \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The oceans dwell in Truth because of their encounter[?] with Priyavrata [Manu's son].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>ŁPāda$ b, Łsamayena priyavrataḥ$, probably stand for Łsamayena priyavratasya$ although
        it is unclear to me what exactly Łsamaya$ refers to here.
        <sep/>
        For Priyavrata's story, in which he wanted to turn nights into days by 
        circling aroung Mount Meru in a chariot, and by this produced the seven oceans,
         see e.g. Bhāgavatapurāṇa 5.1.30--31:<br/> 
        Łyāvad avabhāsayati suragirim anuparikrāman bhagavān ādityo
         vasudhātalam ardhenaiva pratapaty ardhenāvacchādayati, tadā hi [priyavrataḥ]
         bhagavadupāsanopacitātipuruṣaprabhāvas tad anabhinandan samajavena
         rathena jyotirmayena rajanīm api dinaṁ kariṣyāmīti saptakr̥tvas 
         taraṇim anuparyakrāmad dvitīya iva pataṅgaḥ|
         ye vā u ha tadrathacaraṇanemikr̥taparikhātās te sapta sindhava āsan
         yata eva kr̥tāḥ sapta bhuvo dvīpāḥ|$ 
        </NOTE>
        (see translation on pp.640 ff)

Is the Bhāgavatapurāṇa not too late? Priyavrata not in the epics. Mentioned in the Devībhāgavata/mahāpurāṇa
%Cf.\ Purāṇic Encyclopedia, s.v. Łpriyavrata$:
%``Priyavrata once circled round Meru in his chariot. As
%if competing with the Sun Priyavrata started his circling
%along with sunrise and ended it at sunset. He did so
%seven days making nights look like day and the sun
%appear dim and faded. The Sun was dejected and it
%was at the request of the Trimūrtis that Priyavrata
%stopped his circumambulation. It was the path of Priyavrata's
%circling for seven days that later became the seven
%oceans of Purāṇic fame. (Yuddha Kāṇḍa, Kamba Rāmāyaṇa).''

% Judit the vidhya is the vardhamāna... there is a story with Agastya
<TEXT> satyena vindhyās{ }tiṣṭhanti vardhamāno na vardhate||</TEXT> 4.13
<APP>\vc <LEM>vindhyās{ }tiṣṭhanti</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc;                        vindhyas{ }tiṣṭhanti \msCb\msNb, vindhyā tiṣṭhanti \msCc, tiṣṭhate vindhyo \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>It is because of Truth that the Vindhya mountain stands in place and that
                although is was growing it is not growing [anymore].</TR> -->
        <NOTE><sep/>Pādas cd refer to the story of Agastya and the Vindhya mountain:
        Vindhya became jealous of the Sun's revolving around Mount Meru and when the Sun 
        refused to him the same favour, he decided to grow higher and obstruct the Sun's movement.
        As a solution to this situation, 
        Agastya asked Vidhya to bend down to make it easier for him to reach the south and
        to remain thus until he retured. Vindhya agreed to do what Agastya asked him to do 
        but Agastya never returned. See Mahābhārata 3.102.1--14 (see in the word Łsamaya$ in verse 13
                and compare it to VSS 4.12b):
                <sep/>
        Ł                yudhiṣṭhira uvāca |<br/>
                         kimarthaṁ sahasā vindhyaḥ pravr̥ddhaḥ krodhamūrchitaḥ |<br/>
                         etad icchāmy ahaṁ śrotuṁ vistareṇa mahāmune ||<br/>
                         lomaśa uvāca |<br/>
                         adrirājaṁ mahāśailaṁ meruṁ kanakaparvatam |<br/>
                         udayāstamaye bhānuḥ pradakṣiṇam avartata ||<br/>
                         taṁ tu dr̥ṣṭvā tathā vindhyaḥ śailaḥ sūryam athābravīt |<br/>
                         yathā hi merur bhavatā nityaśaḥ parigamyate ||<br/>
                         pradakṣiṇaṁ ca kriyate mām evaṁ kuru bhāskara |<br/>
                         evam uktas tataḥ sūryaḥ śailendraṁ pratyabhāṣata ||<br/>
                         nāham ātmecchayā śaila karomy enaṁ pradakṣiṇam |<br/>
                         eṣa mārgaḥ pradiṣṭo me yenedaṁ nirmitaṁ jagat ||<br/>
                         evam uktas tataḥ krodhāt pravr̥ddhaḥ sahasācalaḥ |<br/>
                         sūryācandramasor mārgaṁ roddhum icchan paraṁtapa ||<br/>
                         tato devāḥ sahitāḥ sarva eva; sendrāḥ samāgamya mahādrirājam |<br/>
                         nivārayām āsur upāyatas taṁ; na ca sma teṣāṁ vacanaṁ cakāra ||<br/>
                         athābhijagmur munim āśramasthaṁ; tapasvinaṁ dharmabhr̥tāṁ variṣṭham |<br/>
                         agastyam atyadbhutavīryadīptaṁ; taṁ cārtham ūcuḥ sahitāḥ surās te ||<br/>
                         devā ūcuḥ |<br/>
                         sūryācandramasor mārgaṁ nakṣatrāṇāṁ gatiṁ tathā |<br/>
                         śailarājo vr̥ṇoty eṣa vindhyaḥ krodhavaśānugaḥ ||<br/>
                         taṁ nivārayituṁ śakto nānyaḥ kaś cid dvijottama |<br/>
                         r̥te tvāṁ hi mahābhāga tasmād enaṁ nivāraya ||<br/>
                         lomaśa uvāca |<br/>
                         tac chrutvā vacanaṁ vipraḥ surāṇāṁ śailam abhyagāt |<br/>
                         so 'bhigamyābravīd vindhyaṁ sadāraḥ samupasthitaḥ ||<br/>
                         mārgam icchāmy ahaṁ dattaṁ bhavatā parvatottama |<br/>
                         dakṣiṇām abhigantāsmi diśaṁ kāryeṇa kena cit ||<br/>
                         yāvadāgamanaṁ mahyaṁ tāvat tvaṁ pratipālaya |<br/>
                         nivr̥tte mayi śailendra tato vardhasva kāmataḥ ||<br/>
                         evaṁ sa samayaṁ kr̥tvā vindhyenāmitrakarśana |<br/>
                         adyāpi dakṣiṇād deśād vāruṇir na nivartate ||<br/>
                         etat te sarvam ākhyātaṁ yathā vindhyo na vardhate |<br/>
                         agastyasya prabhāvena yan māṁ tvaṁ paripr̥cchasi || $
</NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣv{ }asteyam (3)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The third yama-rule: Refraining from stealing</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> anarthayajña uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Anarthayajña spoke:</TR> -->

<TEXT> steyaṁ śr̥ṇv{ }atha viprendra pañcadhā parikīrtitam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kīrtitam</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °kīrttitām \msCb</APP>

                                which is taught to be of five kinds.</TR> -->

% vyāja is interest? Nirajan (Arthaśāstra)
ITTEN
Tr. by R. Shamasastry (1956):
2.6.10: mūlyaṁ bhāgo vyājī parighaḥ kl̥ptam rūpikam atyayaś cāyamukham|
`Capital (mūla), share (bhāga), premia (vyāji), parigha[2](?), fixed taxes (kl̥pta), premia on coins (rūpika[3]) and fixed fines (atyaya) are several forms of revenue (āyamukha, i.e. the mouth from which income is to issue).'
2.6.22: vikriye paṇyānām arghavr̥ddhir upajā, mānaunmānaviśeṣo vyājī, krayasaṁgharṣe vārdhavr̥ddhiḥ - ity āyaḥ ||
`The rise in price of merchandise due to the use of different weights[6] and measures in selling is termed vyājī; the enhancement of price due to bidding among buyers is also another source of profit.'
vyāji = 'Transaction tax ' ( https://www.gktoday.in/gk/kautilyas-system-of-tax-administration )

<TEXT> stenastulya na mūḍham{ }asti puruṣo dharmārthahīno 'dhamaḥ</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>stenastulya</LEM> \Ed; stenatulya \msCa\msCb\msNc\ \unmetr, steyastulya \msCc,                         steyatulya \msNa\ \unmetr, tena tulya \msNb\ \unmetr</APP>
        <NOTE>Understand Łstenastulya na mūḍham{ }asti$ (the reading of \Ed!) as a `metri causa' version of
                Łstenatulyo na mūḍho 'sti$, and see a similar case of a nominative ending
                inside of compound in pāda c below. One major concern remains here:
                the accepted reading here is that of \Ed, an edition that rarely emerges as 
                the sole transmitter of the best reading. A solution could be 
                to emend to Łstenaṁtulya...$, meaning `There is no bigger foolishness than theft',
                but then the second part of pāda a is difficult to connect. 
                <sep/> </NOTE>

<APP>\vc <LEM>prāptaḥ°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\Ed; prāpta° \msNa</APP>

                                 difficulties, propelled by [his] karma.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Łprāptaḥśāsana tīvrasahyaviṣamaṁ$ in pāda c as Łprāptaśāsanas tīvram asahyaṁ ca viṣamaṁ prāpnoti$.

                <sep/>
                The actual reading of \msCa, Łprāptaś$ (lost in the process of normalization and standing
                        in contrast with that of all other MSS that read Łprāptaḥ$) may suggest
                        a doubling of the Łś$ of Łśāsana$ metri causa (suggestion by Törzsök).
                        More likely is that a licence of having a nominative ending inside of a compound
                        is applied here, as probably above in pāda a (also remarked by Törzsök).</NOTE>

<TEXT> aṣṭamūrtiḥ śivaḥ sākṣāt{ }pañcavyomasamanvitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°mūrtiḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °mūrti° \Ed</APP>

MW: aṣṭamūrti (m.) ‘eight-formed’, a N. of Śiva (as identified with the five elements, mind, egotism, and Prakr̥ti [matter]; or, according to the opening of the Śakuntalā, with the five elements, the sun and moon and the sacrificing priest), [MBh. iii, 1939]; [Ragh. &c.] 

% Judit sa nr̥śaṁsakaḥ --> tadnr̥śaṁsakaḥ ? REVISE
<TEXT> sūryaḥ somaś{ }ca dīkṣaś{ }ca dūṣakaḥ tannr̥śaṁsakaḥ||</TEXT> 4.32
<APP>\vc <LEM>sūryaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; <UNCL>sūrya°</UNCL> \msNb\msNc, sūrya° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>dīkṣa°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; <UNCL>dī</UNCL>¤ \msNb, dīkṣu° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tannr̥°</LEM> \emeTorzsok; sa nr̥° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Śiva in his manifest form (Łsākṣāt$) is of eight forms, with the five elements (vyoman! NOTE),
                and the Sun, the Moon, and the sacrificer. [He who] disgraces [any of these] is a cruel person.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>See Śakuntalā 1.1:
        <sep/>
                        Łyā sr̥ṣṭiḥ sraṣṭur ādyā [1] vahati vidhihutaṁ yā havir [2] yā ca hotrī [3]<br/>
                        ye dve kālaṁ vidhattaḥ [4,5] śruti-viṣaya-guṇā yā [6] sthitā vyāpya viśvam |<br/>
                        yām āhuḥ sarva-bīja-prakr̥tir [7] iti yayā prāṇinaḥ prāṇavantaḥ [8]<br/>
                        pratyakṣābhiḥ prapannas tanubhir avatu vas tābhir aṣṭābhir īśaḥ ||$<br/>
                        <br/>
                 The eight Łtanu$s here are: [1] jala [2] agni [3] yajamāna [4,5] sūrya + candra [6] ākāśa [7] bhūmi [8] vāyu
                <sep/>
                For a similar interpretation of Łaṣṭamūrti$, see e.g. Īśānaśivagurudevapaddhati 2.29.34 (Łmantrapāda$;
                                note Łyajamāna$ for our Łdīkṣa$):
                                        Łkṣmā-vahni-yajamānārka-jala-vāyv-indu-puṣkaraiḥ$|
                                        Łaṣṭābhir mūrtibhiḥ śambhor dvitīyāvaraṇaṁ smr̥tam$||
                (For Łpuṣkara$ as `sky, atmosphere', see e.g. Amarakośa 1.2.167:
                        Łdyodivau dve striyām abhraṁ vyoma puṣkaram ambaram$.)
                A closely related Aṣṭamūrti-hymn appears in Niśv mukha 1.30--41 (I owe thanks to Nirajan Kafle
                        for drawing my attention to this); see Kafle 2018: 62, 63, 116, 119. Kafle notes
                        that this hymn is closely parallel to some passages in the Prayogamañjarī (1.19--26),
                        the Tantrasamuccaya (1.16--23), and the Īśānaśivagurudevapaddhati (kriyāpāda 26.56--63). 
                                       See also TAK I s.v. Łaṣṭamūrti$.</NOTE>

11:07:09 From Kengo Harimoto To Everyone : 
Vācaspatyam
skandapurāṇe 
tr̥ṇāni khādanti vasanty araṇye pibanti toyāny aparigrahāṇi.
duhyanti vāhyanti punanti pāpaṁ gavāṁ rasair jīvati jīvalokaḥ.
tuṣṭās tu gāvaḥ śamayanti pāpaṁ dattās tu gāvas tridivan nayanti.
saṁrakṣitāś copanayanti tittaṁ 
gobhir na tulyaṁ dhanam asti kiñcit.
śaṣpaṁ samaśnāti dadāti nityaṁ 
pāpakṣatiṁ mitravivardhanaṁ ca.
sa eva cāryaiḥ paribhujyate ca 
gobhirna tulyaṁ dhanamasti kiñcit.
tr̥ṇāni śuṣkāṇi vane caritvā 
pītvāpi toyāny amr̥taṁ sravanti.
yadgomayādyāś ca punanti lokān 
gobhir na tulyaṁ dhanam asti kiñcit.

Revise!
CsK: but this is in the Śivadharmottara!

<TEXT> atithir{ }yasya tuṣyeta nr̥śaṁsamatam{ }utsr̥jet|</TEXT>
<APP>\vb <LEM>nr̥śaṁsamatam{ }utsr̥jet</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; nr̥śaṁsamata utsr̥jet \msCb,                             nr̥śaṁsakamamam{ }utsr̥jet \msCc, nr̥sasamatam{ }utsr̥jet \msNb, na saṁśaya samaśnute \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>he whose guest is satisfied [and] he who can abandon the sentiment of cruelty,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The demonstrative pronoun Łtasya$ in pāda c may refer to the guest:
              `he will obtain all his [i.e. the guest's] merits', hinting at some sort of karmic exchange.
                Nevertheless, I think that Łtasya$ points at the merits one can obtain by rituals listed 
                in the previous verse. This is suggested by passages such as the following:
                <sep/>
                Mahābhārata Supp. 13.14.379 ff.:<br/>
                   <skt>ahany ahani yo dadyāt kapilāṁ dvādaśīḥ samāḥi|<br/>
                        māsi māsi ca satreṇa yo yajeta sadā naraḥ|| <br/>
                        gavāṁ śatasahasraṁ ca yo dadyāj jyeṣṭhapuṣkare| <br/>
                        na taddharmaphalaṁ tulyam <b>atithir yasya tuṣyati</b>||</skt>
                <sep/>
                 Brahmavaivartapurāṇa 3.44--46:<br/>
                   <skt>atithiḥ pūjito yena pūjitāḥ sarvadevatāḥ|<br/>
                        <b>atithir yasya santuṣṭas</b> tasya tuṣṭo hariḥ svayam||<br/>
                        snānena sarvatīrtheṣu sarvadānena yat phalam|<br/>  
                        sarvavratopavāsena sarvayajñeṣu dīkṣayā|| <br/>
                        sarvais tapobhir vividhair nityair naimittikādibhiḥ|  <br/>
                        tad evātithisevāyāḥ kalāṁ nārhanti ṣoḍaśīm||</skt> 
        </NOTE>

        <!-- <TR>Therefore one should go up to the arriving guest with respectfully joined palms.</TR> -->

<TEXT> saktuprasthena caikena yajña āsīn{ }mahādbhutaḥ|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>saktu°</LEM> \eme; śanku° \msCa\msCb, śaṁktu° \msCc, śaktu° \msNa\msNc, śakthu° \msNb, śakti° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>caikena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; cekena \msNc</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>āsīn{ }mahādbhutaḥ</LEM> \corr; āsīn{ }mahadbhutaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb, āsī mahadbhutaḥ \msCc,                                               āsīt{ }mahādbhutaḥ \msNc, āsīn{ }mahadbhutam \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>By one Łprastha$ of coarsely ground grains</TR> -->
        <NOTE>This verse is a reference to the story related by a mongoose in MBh 14.92--93: 
                A Brahmin who practises the vow of gleaning (Łuñcha$) and his family
                receive a guest. They feed the guest with the last morsels of the little food
                they have. In the end, the guest reveals that he is in fact Dharma (14.93.80cd) and as 
                a reward the family departs to heaven. The noble act of the poor Brahmin and his family
                is depicted as yielding greater rewards than Yudhiṣṭhira's grandiose horse-sacrifice. 
                (See some remarks on this story in Takahashi 2021.)</NOTE>

<TEXT> atithiprāptadānena svaśarīraṁ divaṁ gatam||</TEXT> 4.48
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dānena</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °prādānena \msCc</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>sva°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; <UNCL>sa°</UNCL> \msNc, sa° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°gatam</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °gataḥ \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>given to a guest, an extremely great sacrifice was performed [so to say],
        and his [the Brahmin's and his family members'] bodies (Łsvaśarīraṁ$) reached heaven.</TR> -->
         <NOTE><sep/>We would be forced to accept the reading of \Ed\ in pāda d if the expression
                were in the masculine (Łsaśarīro divaṁ gataḥ$). This would make sense
                and it would also echo expressions occuring e.g. in the Mahābhārata:
                3.164.33cd: <skt>paśya puṇyakr̥tāṁ lokān saśarīro divaṁ vraja</skt>;
                14.5.10cd:  <skt>saṁjīvya kālam iṣṭaṁ ca saśarīro divaṁ gataḥ</skt>.
                It is tempting to emend the pāda accordingly, but I have retained 
                        Łsvaśarīraṁ divaṁ gatam$ and I interpret it as 
                        referring to the Brahmin's whole family (Łsva$).
                </NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu damaḥ (5)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The fifth yama-rule: Self-restraint</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> dama eva manuṣyāṇāṁ dharmasārasamuccayaḥ|</TEXT> 
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dharmasāra°</LEM> \eme; dharmaḥ sāra° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, dharmabhāra° \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vb Łcf.\ Mahābhārata Indeces 14.4.2477: $ śrotum icchāmi kārtsnyena dharmasārasamuccayam</PARAL>
        <!-- <TR>Self-restraint of humans is in itself the collected essence of Dharma.</TR> -->
% see MBh e.g. maybe quote some for support
% a work called dharmasārasamuccaya:
% http://catalogue-old.ngmcp.uni-hamburg.de/mediawiki/index.php/C_44-8(7)_S%C4%81rasamuccaya

<TEXT> damo dharmo damaḥ svargo damaḥ kīrtir{ }damaḥ sukham||</TEXT> 4.50
        <APP>\vc <LEM>svargo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; svarga \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kīrtir{ }da°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\Ed; kīrti da° \msCc\msNa\msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Self-restraint is Dharma, Self-restraint is heaven, 
                 Self-restraint is fame, Self-restraint is happiness.</TR> -->

%                                              damaḥs \msCc
<TEXT> damo yajño damas{ }tīrthaṁ damaḥ puṇyaṁ damas{ }tapaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>damas{ }tī°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dama tī° \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR> Self-restraint is sacrifice, Self-restraint is a pilgrimage-place, 
                  Self-restraint is merit, Self-restraint is religious austerity.</TR> -->

% hīnam sandhi bridge?
<TEXT> damahīna{-}m{-}adharmaś{ }ca damaḥ kāmakulapradaḥ||</TEXT> 4.51
<APP>\vd <LEM>damaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; dama \msCc, damaṁ \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>kāma°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; kāmaṁ \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>If one has no Self-restraint, there is no Dharma, 
                 [while] Self-restraint yields a multitude of desired objects.</TR> -->
% if everything else is there but no dama
% JT maybe kula = family, kula is usually animate, 
% Flo kulakāmaprada?
% CsK emend to kāmaphala? or kāmasukhaprada (Śivadharmaśāstra)

% unmetr!
<TEXT> nirdamaḥ kari mīnaś{ }ca pataṅgabhramaramr̥gāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°damaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °dama \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°bhramara°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed\ \unmetr; °bhrama<UNCL>rā</UNCL>° \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The elephant, the fish, the moth, the bee and the deer are without Self-restraint.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note Łkari$ for Łkarī$ metri causa, and the end of pāda b (Ł°mr̥gāḥ$), which 
                        should be treated metrically as if it read Ł°mrigāḥ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> purūravo 'tilobhena atikāmena daṇḍakaḥ|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>purūravo</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; purorave \msCc, pururavā° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>tilobhena atikāmena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; tikāmena atilobhena \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>daṇḍakaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; puṇḍakaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>Purūravas (double sandhi originally? purūravās ati° -- purūravā ati° -- purūravāti°).
        Pāda a may refer to the following passage in the Mahābhārata (1.70.16--18, 20ab):
        <br/>
                                 <skt>purūravās tato vidvān ilāyāṁ samapadyata|<br/>
                                 sā vai tasyābhavan mātā pitā ceti hi naḥ śrutam||<br/>
                                 trayodaśa samudrasya dvīpān aśnan purūravāḥ|<br/>
                                 amānuṣair vr̥taḥ sattvair mānuṣaḥ san mahāyaśāḥ||<br/>
                                 vipraiḥ sa vigrahaṁ cakre vīryonmattaḥ purūravāḥ|<br/>
                                 jahāra ca sa viprāṇāṁ ratnāny utkrośatām api||<br/>
                                        ... <br/>
                                 tato maharṣibhiḥ kruddhaiḥ śaptaḥ sadyo vyanaśyata|</skt>
        <sep/>
                        (``The wise Purūravas was born to Ilā. We heard that Ilā 
                                was both his mother and his father. 
                           The great Purūravas ruled over thirteen islands of the ocean
                           and, though human, he was always surrounded by superhuman beings.
                           Intoxicated with his power, Purūravas quarrelled with some Brahmins  
                           and robbed them of their wealth even though they were protesting. [...]
                           Therefore, cursed be the great R̥ṣis, he perished.'')
        <sep/>
        See also Buddhacarita 11.15 (Aiḍa = Purūravas):<sep/>
                <skt> aiḍaś ca rājā tridivaṁ vigāhya<br/> 
                        nītvāpi devīṁ vaśam urvaśīṁ tām|<br/>
                      lobhād r̥ṣibhyaḥ kanakaṁ jihīrṣur  <br/>
                        jagāma nāśaṁ viṣayeṣv atr̥ptaḥ||</skt>
        <sep/>
                For Daṇḍa(ka)'s story, see Rāmāyaṇa 7.71.31 ff.:
                Daṇḍa meets Arajā, a beautiful girl, in a forest and rapes her. As a consequence, her father, Śukra/Bhārgava,
                destroyes Daṇḍa's kingdom, which thus becomes the desolate Daṇḍaka-forest.
                  </NOTE>
        <!-- <TR>Purūravas [perished] by excessive greed, Daṇḍaka by excessive desire,</TR> -->

<TEXT> sāgarāś{ }cātidarpeṇa atimānena rāvaṇaḥ||</TEXT> 4.56
        <APP>\va <LEM>sāgarā°</LEM> \eme; sagara° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, sāgara° \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Sagara's sons by excessive pride, Rāvaṇa by excessive haughtiness,</TR> -->
        <NOTE><sep/>For two versions of the destruction of
                Sagara's sons, who were chasing the sacrificial horse of their father's Aśvamedha sacrifice,
                and by doing so disturbed Kapila's meditation, and who in turn burnt them to ashes,
                see Mahābhārata 3.105.9 ff. and Brahmāṇḍapurāṇa 2.52--53.
                <sep/>
                As for Rāvaṇa's haughtiness,
                especially the fact that he chose to be invincible by all creatures except humans,
                and its consequences,
                one should recall the story of the Rāmāyaṇa and Rāvaṇa's destruction brought about by Rāma therein.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msCa\ 396.jpg
<TEXT> atikrodhena saudāsa atipānena yādavāḥ|</TEXT> 
        <APP>\vb <LEM>atipānena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; atipāpena \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Saudāsa by excessive anger, the Yādavas by excessive drinking,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Saudāsa, also known as Kalmāṣapāda, hit Śakti, Vasiṣṭha's son, with a whip because
                the latter did not give way to him, and as a consequence Śakti cursed Saudāsa:
                Saudāsa had to roam the world as a Rākṣasa for twelve years. 
                See Mahābhārata 1.166.1 ff.
                <sep/>
                As for the end of the Yādavas, see the short Mausalaparvan of the Mahābhārata (canto 16):
                cursed by the sages Viśvāmitra, Kaṇva and Nārada, and seeing menacing omens,
                the Yādavas take to drinking in Prabhāsa and destroy each other.
        </NOTE>
% check Saudāsa's death

<TEXT> atitr̥ṣṇāc{ }ca māndhātā nahuṣo dvijavajñayā||</TEXT> 4.57
<APP>\vc <LEM>atitr̥ṣṇāc{ }ca māndhātā</LEM> \conj;atitr̥ṣṇā ca māndāto \msCa,atitr̥ṣṇā ca māndhāto \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc,atitr̥ṣṇā ca mandhāto \msNb,                atitr̥ṣṇā ca mānāc{ }ca ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>nahuṣo</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; naghuṣo \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Māndhātr̥ by excessive desire, Nahuṣa by contempt for Brahmins,</TR> -->
        <NOTE><sep/>Most probably, Łatitr̥ṣṇā$ in the MSS stand for Łatitr̥ṣṇāt$ (intending Łatitr̥ṣṇayā$).
                The form Łmāndhāto$ in \msCb\ stands for Łmāndhātā$ (nominative of Łmāndhātr̥$).
                I have corrected it in spite of the fact that the authors' knowledge about his story may
                come from Divyāvadāna 17, where it sometimes appears to be an a-stem noun (Łmāndāta$).
                Łdvijavajñayā$ in Łpāda$ d stands for Łdvijāvajñayā$ metri causa.
                <sep/>
                Māndhātr̥ was born from his father's body who, being excessively thirsty once,
                had drank some decoction prepared for ritual purposes and as a result become pregnant with him.
                Nevertheless, Buddhacarita 11.13 suggests that Māndhātr̥ himself was still unsatisfied
                with wordly objects even after he had obtained half of Indra's throne:
                <sep/>
                <skt>                devena vr̥ṣṭe 'pi hiraṇyavarṣe  <br/>
                                        dvīpān samagrāṁś caturo 'pi jitvā|  <br/>
                                     śakrasya cārdhāsanam apy avāpya   <br/>
                                        māndhātur āsīd viṣayeṣv atr̥ptiḥ||</skt> <sep/>
                In fact, as Monika Zin points out (2012: 149) Māndhātr̥/Māndhāta's rise and fall is a very popular theme
                in the `Narrative Art of the Amaravati School': 
                ``Statistics show that in the Amaravati School the most frequently represented narrative is
                  the story of King Māndhātar, which appears 47 times.''
        See ibid. p. 151:
        ''The story [e.g. <i>Divyāvadāna</i> XVII, see more sources in fn. 17 of this article] 
        relates that Māndhātar was a miraculously born <i>cakravartin</i> with Seven
        Jewels who could cause rain to fall so that his subjects could prosper; not usual rain, but rain
        of coins, of grain or of cloth. By virtue of his moral strength alone, Māndhātar conquered the world -
        without any weapons. He conquered all the countries on earth, then Uttarakuru,
        Pūrvavideha and Aparagodānīya, after which he set out to conquer the heavens. When he was
        traversing from one abode of the gods to the next (Nāgas, Sadāmattas, Mālādharas, etc.)
        groups of gods pledged obeisance to him and immediately marched in front of his troops.
        Māndhātar reached the splendid city of the Trayastriṁśa gods atop Sumeru, where Indra, in
        the meeting-hall, bequeathed to him half of his own seat and half of his heavenly realm.
        Māndhātar then ruled together with Indra for an unimaginable period of time during which 36
        Indras changed. One day, shortly after he won a battle against the Asuras, a sinful thought
        came to his mind: why should he rule alongside Indra? It was he, after all, who won the war,
        not Indra - he was better and should, therefore, rule alone.
        At that very moment Māndhatar fell from heaven, down to his former realm, became sick and died.
        Shortly before his death, he preached a sermon to his subjects in which <i>gātha</i>s 
        from the <i>Dhammapada</i> (186--187) appear...''
 
                <sep/>
                Nahuṣa was elevated to the position of Indra for a period of time and he also wanted
                to take Śacī, Indra's wife. Indra instructed Śacī to tell Nahuṣa to 
                harness some R̥sis to a vehicle and use this vehicle to take Śacī. 
                Agastya, one of the R̥ṣis, was insulted even further by Nahuṣa, therefore
                he cursed Nahuṣa, who then fell from the vehicle. See Mahābhārata 12.329.35 ff. and
                the verse in the Buddhacarita (11.14) that follows the one about Māndhātr̥:
        <sep/>
                                <skt>        bhuktvāpi rājyaṁ divi devatānāṁ   <br/>
                                                śatakratau vr̥trabhayāt pranaṣṭe|<br/>
                                             darpān maharṣīn api vāhayitvā  <br/>
                                                kāmeṣv atr̥pto nahuṣaḥ papāta||</skt>
                </NOTE>

Bibl:
Zin, Monika (2012). `Māndhātar, the Universal Monarch, and the Meaning of Representations of the Cakravartin in the Amaravati School, and of the Kings on the Kanaganahalli Stūpa.' In: Buddhist Narrative in Asia and Beyond: In Honour of HRH Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn. On Her Fifty-Fifth Birth Anniversary, Skilling, Peter / McDaniel, Justin (edd.) Bankok: Institute of Thai Studies, Chulalongkon University, vol. I



Buddhacarita:

samudravastrām api gām avāpya  
        pāraṁ jigīṣanti mahārṇavasya 
lokasya kāmair na vitr̥ptir asti  
         patadbhir ambhobhir ivārṇavasya  // 11.12 //

devena vr̥ṣṭe 'pi hiraṇyavarṣe  
        dvīpān (samagrāṁś C samudrāṁś ) caturo 'pi jitvā
śakrasya cārdhāsanam apy avāpya  
        *māndhātur* āsīd viṣayeṣv atr̥ptiḥ  // 11.13 //

bhuktvāpi rājyaṁ divi devatānāṁ   
        śatakratau vr̥trabhayāt pranaṣṭe
darpān maharṣīn api vāhayitvā  
        kāmeṣv atr̥pto *nahuṣaḥ* papāta  // 11.14 //

        nītvāpi devīṁ vaśam urvaśīṁ tām
lobhād r̥ṣibhyaḥ kanakaṁ jihīrṣur  
        jagāma nāśaṁ viṣayeṣv atr̥ptaḥ  // 11.15 //

baler mahendraṁ nahuṣaṁ mahendrād   
        indraṁ punar ye nahuṣād upeyuḥ
svarge kṣitau vā viṣayeṣu teṣu  
        ko viśvased bhāgyakulākuleṣu  // 11.16 //
MBh 12:
Unto her Indra then said, Go and say
unto Nahusha that he should come to thee on a vehicle never used before,
viz., one unto which some Rishis should be harnessed, and arriving at
thine in that state he should wed thee. Indra has many kinds of vehicles
that are all beautiful and charming. All these have borne thee. Nahusha,
however, should come on such a vehicle that Indra himself had not
possessed. Thus counselled by her lord, Sachi left that spot with a
joyous heart. Indra also once more entered the fibres of that
lotus-stalk. Beholding the Queen of Indra come back to heaven, Nahusha
addressed her saying, The time thou hadst fixed is over. Unto him Sachi
said what Indra had directed her to say. *Harnessing a number of great
Rishis unto the vehicle he rode, Nahusha set out from his place for
coming to where Sachi was living.* The foremost of Rishis, viz., Agastya,
born within a jar, of the vital seed of Maitravaruna, beheld those
foremost of Rishis insulted by Nahusha in that way. Him Nahusha struck
with his foot. Unto him, Agastya said,--Wretch, as thou hast betaken
thyself to a highly improper act, do thou fall down on the Earth. Be
olong as the Earth and her hills continue. As soon as these words were
uttered by the great Rishi, Nahusha fell down from that vehicle. The
three worlds once more became master-less. The deities and the Rishis
then united together and proceeded to where Vishnu was and appealed to
him for bringing about the restoration of Indra. Approaching him, they
said,--O holy one, it behoveth thee to rescue Indra who is overwhelmed by
the sin of Brahmanicide. The boon-giving Vishnu replied unto them,
saying,--Let Sakra perform a Horse-sacrifice in honour of Vishnu. He will
then be restored to his former position. The deities and the Rishis began
to search for Indra, but when they could not find him, they went to Sachi
and said unto her,--O blessed lady, go unto Indra and bring him here.
transformed into a snake and do thou continue to live in that form as

<TEXT> damena hīnaḥ puruṣo dvijendra</TEXT>

% gender
<TEXT> svargaṁ ca mokṣaṁ ca sukhaṁ ca nāsti|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>there is no heaven, liberation or happiness.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note how flexible the gender of most nouns is in pāda b: 
                        Łsvarga$, Łmokṣa$ and Łdama$ are usually masculine in standard Sanskrit.</NOTE>

% unmetr:
<TEXT> vijñānadharmakulakīrtināśa</TEXT> 
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nāśa</LEM> \msCb; °nāśo \Ed °nāma \msCa\msCc\msNa, °naśca \msNb, °nāgā \msNc</APP>
        <NOTE>The majority of the witnesses suggest that pāda c ends in a stem form noun (Ł°nāśa$).
                This pāda is unmetrical, or rather it applies the licence of a word-final
                short syllable being counted as potentially long (Ł°dharMA°$). </NOTE>

% unmetr:
<TEXT> bhavanti vipra damayā vihīnāḥ||</TEXT> 4.59

        <!-- <TR>O Brahmin, people without Self-restraint 
                        are the destruction of knowledge, Dharma, family and fame.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note how Łviprā$ in pāda d is probably an attempt in some MSS to restore the metre.
                This pāda is also unmetrical, or rather it applies the licence of a word-final
                short syllable being counted as potentially long (ŁviPRA$).</NOTE>

<TEXT> sūtake mr̥take śauṇḍe varṇabhraṣṭakule naṭe||</TEXT> 4.66
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śauṇḍe</LEM> \msNa; sauṇḍye \msCa\msCc\msNc, śoṇḍye \msCb, <UNCL>sauṇḍe</UNCL> \msNb, sauṇḍo \Ed</APP>
        <PARAL>\vo ŁThis verse is mostly illegible in \msNb$</PARAL>
        <!-- <TR>[e.g.] after birth or death [in the family], in case there are vendors of alcohol,
                in the case of a family having lost their caste, and in the case of a Naṭa [dancer caste?].</TR> -->
% kule ... bahuvrīhi individual
        <NOTE>One should probably understand Łśauṇḍe$ in pāda c as Łśauṇḍike$ (alternatively,
                it may be corrupted from Łṣaṇḍhe$); see both in Vāsiṣṭhadharmaśāstra 14.1--3:
                <sep/>
                <skt>athāto bhojyābhojyaṁ ca varṇayiṣyāmaḥ|
                cikitsaka-mr̥gayu-puṁścalī-ḍaṇḍika-stenābhiśastar-ṣaṇḍha-patitānām annam abhojyam|
                kadarya-dīkṣita-baddhātura-somavikrayi-takṣa-rajaka-śauṇḍika-sūcaka-vārdhuṣika-carmāvakr̥ntānām||</skt> etc.
                <sep/>
                In Olivelle's translation (DhSūtras 1999: 285):
                        ``Next we will describe food that is fit and food that is
                        unfit to be eaten [...] The following are unfit
                        to be eaten: food given by a physician, a hunter, a harlot, a law
                        enforcement agent, a thief, a heinous sinner [...] a
                        eunuch, or an outcaste; as also that given by a miser, a man
                        consecrated for a sacrifice, a prisoner, a sick person, a man who
                        sells Soma, a carpenter, a washerman, a liquor dealer, a spy, an
                        usurer, a leather worker...''
                <sep/>
                In support of reading Łṣaṇḍhe$, see Manu 3.239:
                <sep/>
                        <skt>cāṇḍālaś ca varāhaś ca kukkuṭaḥ śvā tathaiva ca|<br/>
                        rajasvalā ca ṣaṇḍhaś ca nekṣerann aśnato dvijān||</skt></NOTE>
% check sauṇḍa as a jāti ṣaṇḍha ! Judit but also śuṇḍa -- śauṇḍa : connected to bar more likely
% notable examples
