<SUBCHAPTER>yameṣu mādhuryam (9)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The ninth yama-rule: Charm</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% Törzsök
<TEXT> kāyavāṅmanamādhuryaṁ cakṣur{ }buddhiś{ }ca pañcamaḥ|</TEXT>
<APP>\vab <LEM>manamādhuryaṁ ca°</LEM> \eme; °manasā dhūryaś{ }ca° \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc,°mana<UNCL>mā</UNCL>dhūryaś{ }ca° \msCb,                                                       °mana¤dhūrya¤° \msNb, °manasā bhūyaś{ }ca° \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kṣur{ }buddhi°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °kṣu buddhi° \msCc\msNa, ¤¤¤ \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[Charm has five types:] bodily, verbal and mental charm, 
                        [charm of] the eyes and [of one's] thoughts pañcamaḥ.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>My emendation from Ł°manasā dhūryaś$ to Ł°mana-mādhuryaś$ is based on the fact that following the list
                of Łyama$s in 3.16cd--17ab, we need some reference to Łmādhurya$ here and that it is easy to see how this
                 corruption came about: Ł°mano-mādhurya°$ would be unmetrical, thus the form Ł°mana-mādhurya$;
                        Ł°mana-mā°$ is easily corrupted to Ł°manasā°$ (not to mention the fact 
                        that Łmanasā$ comes up in the next verse); 
                        in addition we need five items in this line because of Łpañcamaḥ$.
                        As always, I correct Łmādhūrya$ to Łmādhurya$, although it seems that 
                        the former is acceptable in this text. 
                        I did not correct Łmādhuryaś$ to Łmādhuryaṁ$ because of the corresponding
                        Łpañcamaḥ$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> saumyadr̥ṣṭipradānaṁ ca krūrabuddhiṁ ca varjayet||</TEXT> 4.83
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dānaṁ ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; ¤¤ \msNb, °dānaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°buddhiṁ ca</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNc; buddhiś{ }ca \msCb, °dr̥ṣṭiṁ ca \msCc\Ed, ¤¤¤ \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Giving [others] a friendly glance [is commendable] and one should avoid cruel thoughts.</TR> -->

        <!-- <TR>[Sincerity] in action, in livelihood, in prosperity, in gratifying others [and ...?].</TR> -->

<TEXT> strīdhanotkocavittaṁ ca ārjavo nābhinandati||</TEXT> 4.86
<APP>\ve <LEM>strīdhanotkoca°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; strīdhanaṅgo ca \Ed</APP>

        <!-- <TR>A sincere person does not rejoice in women, wealth, bribery and property.</TR> -->

% Nirajan if he is not ārjava, yajña is in vain
<TEXT> ārjavo na vr̥thā yajña ārjavo na vr̥thā tapaḥ|</TEXT>
<APP>\vab <LEM>ārjavo na vr̥thā yajña ārjavo na vr̥thā tapaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; \om\ \msNaacorr,ārjavo na vr̥thā yajña ārjavo na vr̥thā tapa \msNapcorr,                                                 ārjavo na vr̥thā yajñaś{ }cārrjavo na vr̥thā tapaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Sincerity [means] no sacrifice [performed] idly. Sincerity [means] no austerity [performed] idly.</TR> -->

        <APP>\vcd <LEM>(ārjavoŁ...$ vr̥thāgnayaḥ)</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Sincerity [means] no donation [given] idly. Sincerity [means] no fires [kindled] idly.</TR> -->

<APP>\va <LEM>yamapravibhāgaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; yamavibhāgaḥ \msCc,yamapraribhāgaḥ \msNa, niyamaparibhāgaḥ \Ed</APP>

        <!-- <TR>Thus has been taught this section on the Łyama$-rules, O great Brahmin.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>In pāda a Ł°pra°$ does not make the previous syllable long: this is the phenomenon of
                `muta cum liquida', one of the hallmarks of the ŁVr̥ṣasārasaṁgraha$, 
                that is, syllables such as Łtra, pra, bra, dra$ do not necessarily make the 
                previous syllable long.</NOTE>

<APP>\vb <LEM>°yet{ }taṁ manuṣyaḥ</LEM> \corr; °yet{ }tan{ }manuṣyaḥ \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, °yet{ }ta manuṣyaḥ \msCb,                                                                 °yet{ }tat{ }manuṣyaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Humans should follow them to reach happiness here and in the other world.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>In pāda b, Łparata$ most probably stands for Łparatra$ or Łparataḥ$ metri causa. 
        We may correct it to Łparatra$ (`muta cum liquida').</NOTE>

<TEXT> duritamalapahārī śaṅkarasyājñayāste</TEXT>
<APP>\vc <LEM>durita°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; irita° \Ed</APP>

        <!-- <TR>He'll live by Śaṅkara's command with his filth of sins destroyed.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Ł°malapahārī$ in the MSS stands either for Ł°malāpahārī$ or Ł°malaprahārī$ metri causa. 
                I could have choosen to emend it to Ł°malaprahārī$ (`muta cum liquida' again),
                but I decided not to because Łapahārin$, Łapahāra$
                Łapahāraka$ are used in the text very frequently. See also 8.XX, which contains a very similar expression:
                        Łsakalamalapahāre dharmapañcāśad etat$.</NOTE>

%               EMEND?
<TEXT> vāyusaṁcāradānārthaṁ caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet||</TEXT> 5.10
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°cāradānārthaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °cāraṇārthāya \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>He should eat [as much] food [that fills] two quarters [of the stomach] and drink water [that fills] one quarter.
                 In order to be able to practise breath-control, he should save the remaining quarter.</TR> -->
                % pāda d iambic?
        <NOTE>For similar instructions, see a verse cited in Śaṅkara's commentary ad BhG 6.16:
                                Łuktaṁ hi| 
                                ardhaṁ savyañjanānnasya tr̥tīyam{ }udakasya ca| 
                                vāyoḥ saṁcaraṇārthaṁ tu caturtham{ }avaśeṣayet||$
                               (``Half is for food with sauce, the third part for water,
                               but in order to be able to move the air, he should leave the fourth part [empty].'')
                See also e.g. Aṣṭāṅgahr̥daya 8.46cd-47ab:
                                        Łannena kukṣer dvāv aṁśau pānenaikaṁ prapūrayet|| 
                                        āśrayaṁ pavanādīnāṁ caturtham avaśeṣayet|$
                and Sannyāsopaniṣad 59: 
                                        Łāhārasya ca bhāgau dvau tr̥tīyam udakasya ca| 
                                        vāyoḥ saṁcaraṇārthāya caturtham avaśeṣayet||$ </NOTE>

        <APP>\va <LEM>°svādu°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °svā¤ \msNb, °svāda° \Ed</APP>

        <APP>\vc <LEM>karma</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; kramam \Ed</APP>

        <PARAL>\vo Łcf. Manu 7.86--87 (the latter usually labelled as an additional verse): $

        <!-- <TR>They say that the reward [of donation/generosity] is in every case dependent on the

% stem form or ma-vipulā

        <APP>\vd <LEM>°pātaka°</LEM>  \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °pāpaka° \msCa</APP>

<TEXT> dhārayet{ }satataṁ vipra suvarṇakaṭakāṅgulim|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kaṭakāṅgulim</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °ka¤¤gulim \msCa, °kaṭakāṅgulam \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Should one hand over [to someone] a golden bracelet or ring, O Brahmin,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łaṅguli$ is used here in the sense of Łaṅgulīya$ (`finger-ring').</NOTE>

<TEXT> mucyate sarvapāpebhyo rāhunā candramā yathā||</TEXT> 7.15
        <!-- <TR>he will be freed of all sins, just as the moon is freed from [the demon] Rāhu.</TR> -->
        <PARAL>\vcd Ł = 22.38 CHECK $</PARAL>

% ma-vipulā:
<TEXT> dattvā suvarṇaṁ viprebhyo devebhyaś{ }ca dvijarṣabha|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>suvarṇaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; suvarṇa \msNb</APP>

        <!-- <TR>If a person donates  gold to Brahmins or gods, O excellent Brahmin,</TR> -->

<TEXT> tuṭimātre 'pi yo dadyāt{ }sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate||</TEXT> 7.16
<APP>\vc <LEM>tuṭi°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; truṭi° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°mātre</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; °mātro \msNa\Ed</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>sarvapāpaiḥ pramucyate</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc;                                 sarvapāpaiḥ sa mucyate \msCa, sarvapāpai pramucyate \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>even if it is only in a minute quantity, he will be freed of all sins.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The form Łtuṭi$ as a widespread variant of Łtuṭi$, see e.g. CHECK.</NOTE>

% units of measure:
<TEXT> raktimāṣakakarṣaṁ vā palārdhaṁ palam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>raktimāṣaka°</LEM> \msNcacorr; rantimāṣaka° \msCa, rattimāṣaka° \msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr,                                                        rantimmānsaka° \msCc, rattimānsaka° \msNb, rattimāṣaka° \Ed </APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°rdhaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\Ed; °ddha \msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[The amount can be just] one Łrakti$, a Łmāṣaka$, a Łkarṣa$, half a Łpala$ or a Łpala$:</TR> -->
% raktikā  f. Abrus Precatorius (its seed or grain is used as a weight = 1/6, 1/7, or 2/15 Māṣaka), ŚārṅgS.
% karṣa  mn. a weight of gold or silver (= 16 Māṣas = 80 Rettis = 1/4 Pala = 1/400 of a Tulā = about 176 grains troy
 in common use 8 Rettis are given to the Māṣa, and the Karṣa is then about 280 grains troy), Suśr.


<TEXT> evam{ }eva phalaṁ vr̥ddhir{ }jñeyā dānaviśeṣataḥ||</TEXT> 7.17
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>vr̥ddhir{ }jñeyā</LEM> \msCa\Ed; vr̥ddhi jñeyā \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb, vr̥rddhi jñeyā \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>this is exactly how the increase in the [size of the corresponding] reward will be, 
                                in proportion to the kind [i.e.\ amount] of the donation.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I suspect that Łphalaṁ vr̥ddhir$ stands for Łphalavr̥ddhir$ (Łphalasya vr̥ddhiḥ$) metri causa, meaning
                                `the increase of the reward'.</NOTE>

        <!-- <TR>If there is anything that equals the donation of land, O Brahmin, you should really tell me.</TR> -->

<TEXT> mātr̥kukṣivimuktas{ }tu dharaṇīśaraṇo bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°muktas{ }tu</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °muktis{ }tu \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°śaraṇo</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; °śaraṇa \msNc, °śaraṇāṁ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[Humans] have the earth as their abode as soon as they get out of their mother's womb.</TR> -->

<TEXT> carācarāṇāṁ sarveṣāṁ bhūmiḥ sādhāraṇā smr̥tā||</TEXT> 7.20
        <!-- <TR>Land is taught as common to all that is mobile and immobile.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I take Łsādhāraṇā$ as one word, but it is possible that the intention of the author
                        was Łsā dhāraṇā$ in two words, in fact meaning Łsādhāraḥ$ (Łsā ādhāraḥ$, `it is the basis').</NOTE>

<TEXT> ekahastaṁ dvihastaṁ vā pañcāśac{ }chatam{ }eva vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>ekahastaṁ</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc; ekahasta° \msCa\msCc\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Be it [only a land of] one forearm, two forearms, fifty or a hundred,</TR> -->

%folioinfo \msNa\ 205.jpg upper, f.11v

<APP>\vd <LEM>bhūmidānaṁ praśasyate</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; bhūmidāna praśasyate \msCb,                        pañcāśac{ }chatam{ }eva vā| sahāyutalakṣam{ }vā bhūmidaṁ praśasyate \msNb\ Ł(eyeskip)$</APP>
        <!-- <TR>a thousand, ten thousand, a hundred thousand, donations of land are held in great esteem.</TR> -->

%folioinfo \msCb\ 422.jpg, f.210v
<TEXT> ekahastāṁ ca yo bhūmiṁ dadyād{ }dvijavarāya tu|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°hastāṁ ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °hastañ{ }ca \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dadyād{ }dvi°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; dadyā dvi° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Should he donate a piece of land of [only] one forearm to an excellent Brahmin,</TR> -->

<TEXT> varṣakoṭiśataṁ divyaṁ svargaloke mahīyate||</TEXT> 7.22
        <!-- <TR>he will enjoy a billion divine years in heaven.</TR> -->

<TEXT> evaṁ bahuṣu hasteṣu guṇāguṇi phalaṁ smr̥tam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>guṇāguṇi°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; guṇāgaṇi° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Thus in case of many forearms [of land], the reward is said to be 
                        [proportional to the dimensions of the land, i.e.] ...  </TR> -->

<TEXT> śraddhādhikaṁ phalaṁ dānaṁ kathitaṁ te dvijottama||</TEXT> 7.23
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°dhikaṁ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb; °dhika° \msCa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°ttama</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; °ttamaḥ \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>O Brahmin, I have taught you about the rewards of donation that is made willingly.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I think that Łguṇāguṇi$, or perhaps Łguṇaguṇi$ (which would be unmetrical), should refer to the idea
                        that e.g. the donation of a piece of land of 2 x 2 Łhasta$s would result in 
                        4 x Łkoṭiśata$ years in heaven, Łguṇa$ generally meaning `times'. But this is only a guess, and
                        it needs to be supported by some similar passage.
                        I suspect that Łpāda$ c is an awkward attempt at saying Łśraddhādhikadāna(sya) phalaṁ$.</NOTE>

% rāmena \msCc\msNa\msNb
<TEXT> jāmadagnyena rāmeṇa bhūmiṁ dattvā dvijāya vai|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>jāmadagnyena</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNc; jāmadagnye¤ \msCa, jāmadagnena \msCc\msNb\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>rāmeṇa</LEM> \msCb\msNc\Ed; rāmena \msCc\msNa\msNb, ¤¤ṇa \msCa</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>dattvā dvi°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dadyād{ }dvi° \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[Paraśu]rāma, the son of Jamadagni, having donated land to the Brahmin [Kaśyapa],</TR> -->
        <NOTE>See entry `Paraśurāma' in Purāṇic Enc.:
                <sep/>
                                To atone for the sin of slaughtering even
                                innocent Kṣatriyas, Paraśurāma gave away all his
                                riches as gifts to brahmins. He invited all the brahmins
                                to Samantapañcaka and conducted a great Yāga there.
                                The chief R̥tvik (officiating priest) of the Yāga was
                                the sage Kaśyapa and Paraśurāma gave all the lands
                                he conquered till that time to Kaśyapa. Then a plat-
                                form of gold ten yards long and nine yards wide was
                                made and Kaśyapa was installed there and worshipped.
                                After the worship was over according to the instructions
                                from Kaśyapa the gold platform was cut into pieces
                                and the gold pieces were offered to brahmins.
                                When Kaśyapa got all the lands from Paraśurāma he
                                said thus:—“Oh Rāma, you have given me all your
                                land and it is not now proper for you to live in my
                                soil. You can go to the south and live somewhere on
                                the shores of the ocean there.” Paraśurāma walked
                                south and requested the ocean to give him some land to
                                live. </NOTE>

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva ca śakralokasakalaṁ dānāj{ }janānandanam</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>śakralokasakalaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; śatrulokasakalaṁ \msNa, śakralokam{ }atulaṁ \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>dānāj{ }ja°</LEM> \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dānā ja° \msCa, dānārja° \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The unequalled world of Śakra [i.e. Indra] [can be reached] only by donations. 
                                Donations make people happy.</TR> -->

<TEXT> dānād{ }eva mahīṁ samasta bubhuje samrāḍ{ }mahīmaṇḍale|</TEXT>
<APP>\vb <LEM>dānād{ }eva</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; dāned{ }eva \msCb</APP>
<APP><LEM>mahīṁ samasta</LEM> \conj; mahīsamāsu \msCb\msCc, mahīṁ samāṁsu \msCa\msNa\msNc,mahī samasta \msNb, mahīyasāṁ sa \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>samrāḍ{ }ma°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; saṁmrāḍ{ }ma° \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Samrāj enjoyed the whole earth in the world only because of donations. CHECK </TR> -->
        <NOTE>Revise.</NOTE>
Purāṇic Enc.:
SAMRĀṬ . The grand-daughter of Manu Svāyambhuva
and the daughter of Priyavrata, who had married the
daughter of Kardama. Ten sons and two daughters
named Samrāṭ and Kukṣi were born to Priyavrata.
(Viṣṇu Purāṇa, Aṁśa 2, Chapter 1).

        <!-- <TR>Five kinds of study are to be pursued by those who wish to
                        be happy in this life and in the other:</TR> -->

<TEXT> śaivaṁ sāṁkhyaṁ purāṇaṁ ca smārtaṁ bhāratasaṁhitām||</TEXT> 8.1
<APP>\vc <LEM>śaivaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; <UNCL>śai</UNCL>laṁ \msCc</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>sāṁkhyaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc\msP\Ed; śāṁkhya \msCc, sākhyaṁ \msNa\msNb</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>smārtaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msP\Ed; smārta \msCc\msNb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>bhāratasaṁhitām</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msP\Ed; bhāratasaṁhitāḥ \msNa, bhārattasaṁhitāṁ \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[one has to study the] Śaiva [teachings], Sāṁkhya [philosophy], the Purāṇa[s],
                the Smārta [tradition] and the ŁBhāratasaṁhitā$ [i.e. the ŁMahābhārata$].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the accusative ending of Ł°saṁhitām$ after a list consisting of words probably in the
                        nominative. One may correct it to Ł°saṁhitā$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> śaivatattvaṁ vicinteta śaivapāśupatadvaye|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>śaiva°</LEM> \conj; śaive \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc, śaivai \msCb\msP, śaivaṁ \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°tattvaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; °tattva \msP</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>śaiva°</LEM> \msP; śaivaḥ \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc, śaivāḥ \msCc\Ed, śaivā \msNa</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°dvaye</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °ye \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>He should reflect on the Śaiva truth in both Śaiva and 
                Pāśupata [teachings].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note that Łśaivatattvaṁ$ in pāda a is the result of a conjecture and that the reading Łśaivapāśupatadvaye$ 
                      in pāda b is based on one single manuscript (\msP). In spite of this uncertainty, 
                      I think that this form of the current half-verse is the only one that yields an appropriate meaning.</NOTE>

<TEXT> atra vistarataḥ proktaṁ tattvasārasamuccayam||</TEXT> 8.2
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sārasamuccayam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\msP\Ed; °sāraṁ samuccayam \msNa, °sāraṁ samudyayaṁ \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>In those teachings the whole essence of truth is taught extensively.</TR> -->
% or in this work?

%folioinfo \msNc\ 222.jpg lower, 220r
<TEXT> adhordhvamadhyatiryaṁ ca yatnataḥ sampraveśayet||</TEXT> 8.4
<APP>\vc <LEM>adhordhva°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msP\Ed; adhordhvaṁ \msNb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°madhya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °madha° \msCc</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>yatnataḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msP\Ed; yatnata \msNb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>sampraveśayet</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; samprabodhayet \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>One can definitely enter [the realm] of the lower [world, i.e. hell], 
                 the upper [world, i.e. heaven], and middle [world, i.e. the human world], 
                 and the horizontal [world, i.e. of animals by studying the Purāṇas].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note that Łtirya$ seems to be an acceptable nominal stem in this text for Łtiryañc$. 
              I understand the causative form Łsampraveśayet$ as non-causative, and 
              interpret °madhya° as the `human world' tentatively.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 205.jpg lower, f.12r 
<TEXT> smārtaṁ varṇāśramācāraṁ dharmanyāyapravartanam|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>smārtaṁ varṇā°</LEM> \msCa; tasmārttam{ }varṇṇā° \msCb,                                        smārtavarṇā° \msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed, smārttaṁ varṇṇa° \msP</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>dharma°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; dharmaṁ \msCc</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°vartanam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °va¤naṁ \msP, °vartana \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The Smārta [tradition] deals with the conduct of the classes (Łvarṇa$) and
                the conduct in the life-stages (Łāśrama$), and with the activities of Dharma and legal proceedings.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Compare pāda a with 3.15c.</NOTE>

<TEXT> śiṣṭācāro 'vikalpena grāhyas{ }tatra aśaṅkitaḥ||</TEXT> 8.5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°cāro</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc; °cāra° \msCc\Ed, °cārā \msNa, °cā<UNCL>ro</UNCL>° \msP</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>grāhyas{ }tatra aśaṅkitaḥ</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; grāhyas{ }ta¤¤¤ṅkitaḥ \msCa</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Good conduct is to be gathered from that [source] without hesitation, with trust.</TR> -->
        <NOTES>The Łavagraha$ in Ł'vikalpena$ is not to be found in the witnesses and has
                therefore been supplied by the editor. The form Łaśaṅkitaḥ$ is less then perfect here,
                and may have been intended as an ablative (Łaśaṅkā-taḥ), as suggested by Judit Törzsök,
                or adverbally (Łaśaṅkitam$), or even more probably as a loosely added subject (for 
                Łaśaṅkitena$).</NOTE>

<TEXT> itihāsam{ }adhīyānaḥ sarvajñaḥ sa naro bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°jñaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °jña \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>A man who studies the epics (Łitihāsa$) will become omniscient.</TR> -->

<TEXT> dharmārthakāmamokṣeṣu saṁśayas{ }tena chidyate||</TEXT> 8.6
        <!-- <TR>[All his] doubts about Dharma, Artha, Kāma and Mokṣa will be eliminated.</TR> -->




<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣv{ }upasthanigrahaḥ (6)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The sixth niyama-rule: Sexual restraint</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> śr̥ṇuṣvāvahito vipra pañcopasthavinigraham|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°graham</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °graha<UNCL>ḥ</UNCL> \msNa</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Listen with great attention, O Brahmin, to 
                        the five types of sexual restraint [concerning the following:]</TR> -->

<TEXT> striyo vā garhitotsargaḥ svayaṁmuktiś{ }ca kīrtyate|</TEXT>
<APP>\vc <LEM>garhitotsargaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb\msNc\msP; garhitas{ }sarggaḥ \msCc, garhito vipra \msNa,                                                                                garhito svargaḥ \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>svayaṁ°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; svaya° \msCb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>kīrtyate</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; kī<UNCL>rtsya</UNCL>te \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>women, forbidden ejaculation, and masturbation are mentioned [in this context, as well as]</TR> -->
% NOTE vā phps to avoid iambic Judit; szerintem nem, mert így is pathyā

%folioinfo \Ed\ p.604
% ma-vipulā
<TEXT> svapnopaghātaṁ viprendra divāsvapnaṁ ca pañcamaḥ||</TEXT> 8.7
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°ghātaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °ghāta \msCc\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>offence while sleeping, O Brahmin, and daydreaming as the fifth.</TR> -->


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>striyaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Women</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> agamyā strī divā parve dharmapatny{ }api vā bhavet|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>strī divā parve</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; ¤ divā parvve \msCa, ¤¤¤ parve \msP, strī divāpūrve \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°patny{ }api</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °patnī pi \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>A woman is not to be approached sexually in daytime and 
                on the four days of the changes of the Moon (Łparvan$), even if she is one's lawful wife. </TR> -->
        <PARAL>\vab Łcf.\ Manu 11.175 (Olivelle's edition): $
                         maithunaṁ tu samāsevya puṁsi yoṣiti vā dvijaḥ |
                         goyāne 'psu divā caiva savāsāḥ snānam{ }ācaret || Łand Manu 3.45 (Olivelle's edition): $
                         r̥tukālābhigāmī syāt{ }svadāranirataḥ sadā |
                         parvavarjaṁ vrajec{ }caināṁ tadvrato ratikāmyayā ||</PARAL>
        <NOTE>Understand Łparve$ as Łparvani$ (thematisation of the stem in Ł-an$).</NOTE>
% ask Judit, e.g. on SYM 6.48cd:
% grāmadharmaṁ sadā varjyaṁ vāsare, siddhim icchatā (also TSBh)

<TEXT> viruddhastrī na seveta varṇabhraṣṭādhikāsu ca||</TEXT> 8.8
        <APP>\vc <LEM>viruddhastrī na</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\msNc; viruddhastrī niseveta \msNa\msP, dviruddhāstrīn{ }na \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>°dhikāsu ca</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msP; °dhikāsu ta \msCc, °dikāṣu ca \msNb,                                                        °vikāṣu ca \msNc, °pikāsu ca \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>One should not have sex with a woman who is taboo or with one of those who have lost their class (Łvarṇa$) or
                        are [of a] superior [Łjāti$ than oneself].</TR> -->

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>garhitotsargaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Forbidden ejaculation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ajameṣagavādīnāṁ vaḍavāmahiṣīṣu ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°meṣa°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °meya° \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Intercourse with goats, sheep, cows, mares, buffaloes</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Ł°ādīnāṁ$ in pāda a as standing for the locative case.</NOTE>

<TEXT> garhitotsargam{ }ity{ }etad{ }yatnena parivarjayet||</TEXT> 8.9
        <!-- <TR>is called forbidden ejaculation, which is to be avoided at all cost.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Ł°sargam$ as neuter nominative (instead of Ł°sargaḥ$) or alternatively
               understand pāda c with a hiatus bridge: Łgarhitotsarga-m-ity etad$.</NOTE>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>svayaṁmuktiḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Masturbation</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> ayonyakaṣaṇā vāpi apānakaṣaṇāpi vā|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>ayonya°</LEM> \conj; anyonya° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°kaṣaṇā</LEM> \msCa\msNa; °karṣaṇā \msCb\msCc\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°kaṣaṇāpi</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; °karṣaṇāpi \msNb\msNc\msP\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Rubbing himself against something else than a female sexual organ or rubbing his anus,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The conjecture that changes Łanyonya°$ to Łayonya°$ in pāda a involves 
                minimal intervention and makes the sentence much more meaningful than the 
                version transmitted. Also consider Łayoni°$.</NOTE>

<TEXT> svayaṁmuktir{ }iyaṁ jñeyā tasmāt{ }tāṁ parivarjayet||</TEXT> 8.10
<APP>\vc <LEM>svayaṁmukti°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; svayamukti° \msCb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>jñeyā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msP\Ed; jñeyāṁ \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>tasmāt{ }tāṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\msP; tasmāt{ }taṁ \msCc, tasmārttā \msNb, tasmāt{ }strī \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>are called masturbation, therefore these are to be avoided.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The variant Łstrī$ for Łtāṁ$ in pāda d in the \Ed\ may be an example of Naraharināth, the editor's 
                        conscious interventions.</NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu vratapañcakam (7)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The seventh niyama-rule: religious observances</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> mārjārakabakaśvānagomahīvratapañcakam|</TEXT>
<APP>\vab <LEM>mārjārakabakaśvānagomahīvrata°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\msP;mārjārabakabaśvānagomahīvrata° \msNb,                                 mārjārakaś{ }ca śvānāś{ }ca gomahīvaka \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[Hear about] the five religious observances [called] the cat, the crane, the dog, the cow, and 
                                the earth.</TR> -->



<SUBSUBCHAPTER>mārjārakavratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>The Cat Vow</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>

% ma-vipulā, °viṣṭhāmūtra would be pathyā
<TEXT> svaviṣṭhamūtraṁ bhūmīṣu chādayed{ }dvijasattama|</TEXT>
<APP>\vc <LEM>°viṣṭha°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °viṣṭā° \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°mūtraṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\msP\Ed; °mūtra° \msCb\msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR><sep/>He buries his own urine and faeces in the ground, O truest Brahmin.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note Ł°viṣṭha°$ for Łviṣṭhā$ metri causa in pāda c (Łma-vipulā$).
                Alternatively, read Łsvaviṣṭhāmūtra bhūmīṣu$.</NOTE> 

% stem form 
<TEXT> sūryasomānumodanti mārjāravratikeṣu ca||</TEXT> 8.13
        <APP>\ve <LEM>°modanti</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °ṣādanti \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>He rejoices [seeing] the sun and the moon when performing the cat observance.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the stem form Łsūryasoma$ for Łsūryasomau$ in pāda e. 
                It is not entirely clear why cats would rejoice seeing the Sun and the Moon.
                Perhaps this remark refers to the fact that cats can be active both
                in the daytime and at night.</NOTE>


<SUBSUBCHAPTER>bakavratam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>The Crane Vow</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> bakavac{ }cendriyagrāmaṁ suniyamya tapodhana|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tapodhana</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msP; tapodhanaḥ \msNc, tapodhanam \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>O great ascetic, one should suppress all of his senses like a crane,</TR> -->
% uncl ba uncl ¤ vacce° 

<TEXT> sādhayec{ }ca manastuṣṭiṁ mokṣasādhanatatparaḥ||</TEXT> 3.14
<APP>\vc <LEM>sādhayec{ }ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; sādhaye ca \msCb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>manastuṣṭiṁ</LEM> \msCa\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; manastuṣṭi° \msCb\msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°sādhana°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msP\Ed; °sāna° \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>and should cultivate the peace of the mind, focusing on achieving liberation.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Cranes are compared to ascetics here probably because of the similarity of
                their tendency of relaxing standing on one leg to ascetics performing penance 
                standing on one leg (such as the ascetic depicted on the famous relief in Mahabalipuram). </NOTE>
% NOTE CHECK conventions

% go for bhīmas?
<TEXT> bhīma tuṣṭikaraś{ }caiva purāṇeṣu nigadyate||</TEXT> 8.16

        <NOTE>I prefer reading Łbhīma tuṣṭi°$ as two separate words, the first
                one in stem form, to reading it as a compound because
                of the following Łcaiva$, and to the reading Łbhīmas tuṣṭi°$ 
                because the corresponding witnesses are the ones that usually give inferior readings.</NOTE>

<APP>\va <LEM>antarā prātarāśī</LEM> \eme; antarā prāntarāśī \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc,antarā <UNCL>kranta</UNCL>rāśī \msNb,                                                antārā prā<UNCL>tta</UNCL>rāśī \msP, antasamprāntarāśī \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>sāyamāśī</LEM> \msCb\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; sāyamāśīn \msCa, niyamāśī \Ed</APP>

%folioinfo \msNa\ 206.jpg upper, f.12v 
<TEXT> sadopavāsī bhavati yo na bhuṅkte kadācana||</TEXT> 8.21
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsī bhavati</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °vāsī ca bhavati \msCc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kadācana</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; kadācanaḥ \msCc</APP>
        <PARAL>\vcd \kb\ ŁMBh 12.214.9:  $antarā prātarāśaṁ ca sāyamāśaṁ tathaiva ca|
                                         sadopavāsī ca bhaved yo na bhuṅkte kathaṁcana|| \kb\
                         ŁMBh 13.93.10: $antarā sāyamāśaṁ ca prātarāśaṁ tathaiva ca|
                                         sadopavāsī bhavati yo na bhuṅkte 'ntarā punaḥ||</PARAL>
                <!-- <TR>He will be regarded as one that is always fasting 
                        if he never eats between breakfast and dinner.</TR> -->
                <NOTE>My translation here follows the parallel verse in the MBh and 
                      is based on that of Kisari Mohan Ganguli. The syntax of the version here in the VSS is less
                      smooth than that in the MBh, and the VSS's reading Łprāntarāśī$ definitely required an emendation.</NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>niyameṣu maunavratam (9)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The ninth niyama-rule: Silence</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> mithyāpiśunapāruṣyatīkṣṇavāg{ }apralāpanam|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°pāruṣya°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °saṁbhinnā \msCc, °yābhinnā \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>°tīkṣṇavāg{ }a°</LEM> \conj;                                °spr̥ṣṭavāg{ }a° \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP, pr̥ṣṭavāk{ }a° \msCc, pr̥ṣtevāk{ }a° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>One should keep these five types of taciturnity,
                   always dwelling in religious observances:</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Łpāruṣya$ seems to be the good reading in pāda a because 
                in the following a short section on this category is coming up.
                As far as the readings Łspr̥ṣṭavāg$ and Łpr̥ṣṭavāg$ are concerned, I suppose 
                Łpr̥ṣṭavāg$ is not inconceivable (as suggested by Judit Törzsök), 
                for in 8.29 it is questions that are given as relevant examples. 
                Nevertheless I conjectured Łtīkṣṇavāg$ here, relying on the same verse, 8.29.</NOTE>

<TEXT> maunapañcakam{ }ity{ }etad{ }dhārayen{ }niyatavrataḥ||</TEXT> 8.25
<APP>\vc <LEM>maunapañcaka°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNb; maunaṁ pañcaka° \msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed, maunam{ }pañca° \msP</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°ty{ }eta°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msPpcorr\Ed; °ty{ }e° \msPacorr</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°rayen{ }ni°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °rayan{ }ni° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>[in situations where silence is best instead of] deceitful speech, envious speech, abuse, harsh speech, bragging.</TR> -->

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>asatpralāpaḥ</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Bragging</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> dyūtabhojanayuddhaṁ ca madyastrīkatham{ }eva ca|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°yuddhaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; °yuddhaś \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°katha°</LEM> \msNb\msNc; °kaṣa° \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msP, °karṣa° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Relating fancy stories about gambling, enjoyments, fights, drinking and women</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I take Ł°katham$ in pāda b as an alternative nominative form of Ł°kathā$ metri causa and as 
                belonging to all the categories here thus: Łdyūtakathā, bhojanakathā, yuddhakathā, madyakathā,
                strīkathā$.</NOTE>

% ma-vipulā
<TEXT> asatpralāpaḥ pañcaitat{ }kīrtitaṁ me dvijottama||</TEXT> 8.30
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>pañcaitat{ }kī°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msP\Ed; pañcaite kī° \msNb, pañcetat{ }kī° \msNc</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>me</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; te \Ed</APP>

<TEXT> bhasmanā r̥ṣayaḥ sarve pavitrīkr̥tam{ }ātmanaḥ||</TEXT> 8.37
        <APP>\vc <LEM>r̥ṣayaḥ sarve</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; r̥ṣibhir{ }sarvaiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>all the R̥ṣis purified themselves with ashes.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Grammatical notes on kr̥tam and ātmanaḥ</NOTE>

<TEXT> bhasmanā vibudhā muktā vīrabhadrabhayārditāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>muktā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP; muktāḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°rditāḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\msNc\msP\Ed; °rttitāḥ \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The gods, afflicted by their fear of Vīrabhadra, were set free with the help of ashes.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>It is not clear which story concerning Vīrabhadra is referred to here. 
                Is it the destruction of Dakṣa's sacrifice, after which the gods were relieved? 
                Or, which is a less likely possibility, another in which 
                Kaśyapa and other R̥ṣis were burnt to ashes then reanimated by Vīrabhadra in the Śokara forest? 
                For the latter, less well-known story, see Padmapurāṇa 5.107.1--14ff:<sep/>
                        Łśucismitovāca <br> 
                        kaśyapaṁ jamadagniṁ ca devānāṁ ca purā katham | <br>
                        rarakṣa bhasma tad brahman samācakṣva mune mama ||1  <br>
                        dadhīca uvāca  <br>
                        kaśyapādiyutā devāḥ pūrvam abhyāgaman girim  |<br>
                        śokaraṁ nāma vikhyātaṁ girimadhye suśobhanam ||2  <br>
                        nānāvihaṁgasaṁkīrṇaṁ nānāmunigaṇāśrayam | <br>
                        vāsudevāśrayaṁ ramyam apsarogaṇasevitam ||3  <br>
                        vicitravr̥kṣasaṁvītaṁ sarvartukusumojjvalam  |<br>
                        tathāvidhaṁ praviśyaite giriṁ vayam athāpare ||4  <br>
                        stuvaṁtaḥ keśavaṁ tatra gatāḥ sma giriśeśvaram  |<br>
                        dr̥ṣṭvā tatra mahājvālāṁ praviṣṭāśca vayaṁ ca tām ||5  <br>
                        māmekaṁ tu tiraskr̥tya hy adahad devatā munīn  |<br>
                        māṁ dadāha tataḥ paścād bhasmībhūtā vayaṁ śubhe ||6<br>  
                        asmān etādr̥śān dr̥ṣṭvā vīrabhadraḥ pratāpavān | <br>
                        kenāpikāraṇenāsau gatavān parvataṁ ca tam ||7  <br>
                        bhasmoddhūlitasarvāṁgo mastakasthaśivaḥ śuciḥ  |<br>
                        ekākī niḥspr̥haḥ śānto hāhāśabdam athāśr̥ṇot ||8  <br>
                        atha ciṁtāparaś cāsīn mriyamāṇa śavadhvaniḥ | <br>
                        śavānām iva gaṁdhaś ca dr̥śyate tannirīkṣaṇe ||9  <br>
                        iti niścitya manasā jagāmāgnim atiprabham  |<br>
                        sa vahnir vīrabhadraṁ ca dagdhum ārabdhavān atha ||10 <br> 
                        tr̥ṇāgnir iva śāṁto 'bhūd āsādya salilaṁ yathā | <br>
                        tato 'parāṁ mahājvālāṁ vīrabhadras tu dr̥ṣṭavān ||11 <br> 
                        khaṁ gacchaṁtīṁ mahākālo jvālāṁ nipatitām api  |<br>
                        manasā ciṁtayac cāpi vīrabhadraḥ pratāpavān ||12  <br>
                        sarveṣāṁ nāśinī jvālā prāṇināṁ śatakoṭiśaḥ | <br>
                        tat sarvaṁ rakṣaṇārthaṁ hi pipāsuś cāpy ahaṁ tv imām ||13  <br>
                        prāśnāmi mahatīṁ jvālāṁ salilaṁ tr̥ṣito yathā | <br>
                        etasminn aṁtare vīraṁ vāg āha cāśarīriṇī ||14$ <sep/>

``Śucismitā said:<br>

1. O brāhmaṇa, O sage, tell me how formerly the sacred ash protected Kaśyapa, Jamadagni of the gods?
Dadhīca said:<br>

2--6. Formerly gods accompanied by Kaśyapa and others went to a well-known mountain named Śokara. In the middle of the mountain was a very beautiful (forest) which was full of many birds, which was resorted to by various hosts of sages, which was the resort of Vāsudeva, which was charming, which was resorted to by bevies of celestial nymphs, which was crowded with strange trees, which was bright with flowers of all seasons. We and others entered the best mountain (forest) like that and praising Viṣṇu went there to lord Śiva. We saw a great flame there and we entered it. Excepting me that deity (i.e. that flame) burnt (other) sages. After that it (also) burnt me. O auspicious one, we were reduced to ash.
<br>
7--14. Seeing us like this, that brave Vīrabhadra went to that mountain for some reason. With his entire body smeared with sacred ash, he remaining at the top, auspicious and pure, all alone, desireless and tranquil, heard the sound of wailing. Then he was full of thought: ‘The sound of the bodies of dead men and the smell as it were of dead bodies, are being perceived.’ Deciding like this in his mind, he went to the fire of great brilliance. Then that fire also started to burn Vīrabhadra. But it went out as the fire of (i.e. burning) grass (i.e. hay) would go out on receiving (i.e. being sprinkled over with) water. Then Vīrabhadra saw a great, mighty flame, which went (up) to the sky even (like) flame falling (i.e. dropped by) Śiva (obscure!). The brave Vīrabhadra thought in his mind: ‘(This) flame is the destroyer of hundreds of crores of beings. So for the protection of all I desire to drink it. As a thirsty man drinks water, I shall consume this great flame.’ In the meanwhile a divine voice said to (Vīrabhadra) the hero [...] (translation by N.A. Deshpande, in: Padma-purāna, Delhi: MLBD, 1951)''
 </NOTE>

<SUBSUBCHAPTER>brāhmyaṁ snānam</SUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>Vedic bath</TRSUBSUBCHAPTER>
<TEXT> brahmasnānaṁ ca viprendra āpohiṣṭhaṁ vidur{ }budhāḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>viprendra</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; vipendra \msNc\msP</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>vidur{ }bu°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msP\Ed; virdur{ }bu° \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>The wise know the Vedic bath as [the one performed with the Vedic mantra beginning] Łāpo hi ṣṭhā$ [R̥V 10.9.1--3],
                        O excellent Brahmin.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The R̥gvedic mantra starting with Łāpo hi ṣṭhā$ (R̥V 10.9) is traditionally associated with 
                Łmārjana$ (`cleaning, wiping'). According to Kane (A History of Dharmaśāstra, vol. 4, p. 120),
                a Brahmin ``should bathe thrice in the day, should perform Łmārjana$ (splashing
                or sprinkling water on the head and other limbs by means of Łkuśas$ 
                dipped in water after repeating sacred mantras) with the three verses `apo hi sthā' [sic] (R̥g. X.9.1--3) [...]''
                This suggests a method of bathing that is more of a ritual than an actual bath.</NOTE>

<TEXT> trisaṁdhyam{ }eva kartavyaṁ brahmasnānaṁ tad{ }ucyate||</TEXT> 8.41
        <!-- <TR>It is to be performed at the three junctures of the day (dawn, noon, evening).
                It is called the Vedic bath.</TR> -->

        <!-- <TR>The one and only great Lord (Łmaheśvara$) of the universe calls it heavenly bath.</TR> -->

<TRSUBCHAPTER>The description of the pilgrimage places in the body</TRSUBCHAPTER>

% yogino na prapadyante svātmapratyayakāriṇaḥ|| 3.63||
% agnau kriyāvatāṁ devā divi devā manīṣiṇām|
% pratimāsvaprabuddhānāṁ yogināmātmani sthitāḥ|| 3.64||
% śivamātmani paśyanti pratimāsu na yoginaḥ|
% ajñānāmbhāvanārthāya pratimā parikalpitā|| 3.65||
% ātmatthaṁ yaḥ śivaṁ tyaktvā bahiḥsthaṁ yajate śivam|
% haste piṇḍaṁ samutsr̥jya lihet kūrparamātmanaḥ|| 3.66||
% sarvatrāvasthitaṁ ye tu na prapaśyanti śaṅkaram|

        <!-- <TR>Maheśvara spoke:</TR> -->

<TEXT> ko māṁ pr̥cchati taṁ praśnaṁ muktvā tvām{ }eva sundari|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>taṁ praśnaṁ</LEM> \msNa\msNb; tat{ }praśna \msCa\msCb, tat{ }praśnaṁ \msCc\Ed,                                                                taṁ praśna \msNc</APP>

%                but in the next line the same manuscript falls back to Łtat praśnaṁ$,
%                treating Łpraśna$ as neuter, as all the other MSS.
        <!-- <TR>Who else would ask me that question if not you, O Sundarī?</TR> -->

<TEXT> śr̥ṇu vakṣyāmi tat{ }praśnaṁ devair{ }api sudurlabham||</TEXT> 10.6
        <APP>\vc <LEM>tat{ }praśnaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; taṁ praśnan \msNc</APP>

        <APP>\vc <LEM>°nāyāsa</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNc\Ed; °nāyā<UNCL>saṁ</UNCL> \msNa, °<UNCL>nāyā</UNCL>saṁ \msNb</APP>

        % °nāyāśa \mssCaCbCc

                 <NOTE>Context: Viśvarūpa was a son of Tvaṣṭr̥. Viśvarūpa's heads were struck off by Indra.

                         water, trees and women.</NOTE>
                        % BhP 6.9.5: ``Thereafter, the head meant for drinking soma-rasa was

                        head meant for eating food became a tittiri [common partridge].''

<TEXT> sādhanaṁ śivasaṁkalpo yogasiddhiphalapradaḥ|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>The Śivasaṁkalpa [hymn] is practice (sādhana), 
                     which yields fruits of yoga accomplishments.</TR> -->
        <APP>\vd <LEM>°daḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb\msNc; °dam \Ed</APP>
        <NOTE>The Śivasaṁkalpa is R̥gvedakhila 4.11 ff:
        yenedam bhūtaṁ bhuvanaṁ bhaviṣyat parigr̥hītam amr̥tena sarvam,
        yena yajñas tāyate saptahotā tan me manaś śivasaṅkalpam astu, etc. 
        See also Manu 11.251ab: sakr̥t japtvāsyavāmīyaṁ śivasaṁkalpam eva ca.</NOTE>
% Monier-Williams: śivasaṁkalpa (śiva-) m. ‘auspicious in meaning’, N. of the text, VS. xxxii, 1-6 (also °pasūkta; also °popaniṣad; cf. Mn. xi, 251).
% perhaps they do practise the recitation of the Śivasaṁkalpa? Yes, see VSS 6.5 above?
        %Kristen: This is the relevant section of Scheftelowitz (Die Apokryphen des R̥gveda, 1906): https://archive.org/details/in.ernet.dli.2015.134238/page/n125/mode/1up. Unfortunately, the digitization leaves much to be desired (in other words, it's kind of illegible).  The hymn with Sāyaṇa's commentary is in vol. 4 of the Pune R̥g-Veda (https://ia800800.us.archive.org/25/items/RgVedaWithSayanasCommentaryPart4/rv_sayanabhasya_part4.pdf). There's also a translation in Usha Bhise's The Khila-Sūktas of the R̥g-Veda (BORI, 1995), but it is sitting uselessly on my external hard drive in Leiden.
        % Kenji: I found a short description of Śivasasṁkalpa in Tsuji’s Existent Yajurveda-Literature. 1970.
        p. 70.
        Śivasaṁkalpa (Vājasaneyīsaṁhitā XXXIV.1-6)
        ・This hymn regards Manas as the highest deity.
        ・Refrain of tan me manaḥ śivasaṁkalpam astu 
        ・Judging from the fact that it is not admitted by Vājasaneyīsaṁhitā of the Kāṇvas, it might be of later origin.
        ・Later expanded to 13 verses (die kāśmirische Rezension) or 28 verses. 
        ・Regarded as the Khila of the RV.
        ・verses 7–13: imitation using the refrain, verses 14–28 Śiva (=Manas) as the highest deity.
        cf. also p. 179 fn. 656-658.
        % CsK: Scheftelowitz, Isidor: »Śivasaṅkalpopaniṣad.« In: Zeitschrift der Deutschen Morgenländischen Gesellschaft 75 (1921), pp. 201-212. DOWNLOADED
        %NiśvGuhya: pāvamānīṁ ca japtavyā śivasaṁkalpa paścime 2:77
%% According to Brunner (1998:126, fn.312), pāvamānī is the
%% 9th maṇḍala of the R̥gVeda. (Can this be right?)
%% Note that 77 gives what the R̥gvedin recites, 78 the Yajurvedin,
%% 79 the Sāmavedin, and 80 the Ātharvana.
        % CsK: the Śivasaṁkalpa is mentioned in a number of texts: Purāṇas, NiśvGuhy, Pauṣkara, Kālottara etc.

Vipula
Kapila, Vipula's father
his wife
a Brahmin guest
a monkey
Bhīmabala, a traveller 
Puṇḍaka, the śreṣṭhin
King Siṁhajaṭa
Queen Kekayī
two envoys of the king
the king of the Gandharvas

        <NOTE>I have taken Łjapayajñāṁś$ in pāda c as a Łtatpuruṣa$ compound. 
                The same expression occurs e.g. in VSS 6.2ff, MBh 13.102.8c, Manu 2.86 etc.
                By this, Łvedāṁś$ becomes difficult to interpret (I supply `recited'). It may be possible to take
                Łjapa$ as a form deriving from Łjapan$ (present participle) metri causa:
                        Łvedāṁś ca japa$[Łn$] yajñāṁś ca kr̥tvā$, but in this case 
                        the notion of performing sacrifices comes up twice in this verse.</NOTE>
        <!-- <TR>[recited] the Vedas, and performed sacrifices of recitation.</TR> -->

%folioinfo \msCc\ 222.jpg f. 289v
<TEXT> āśīḥ suvipulaṁ dattvā vipulāya mahātmane||</TEXT> 12.45
        <!-- <TR>blessed the good-souled Vipula a good number of times,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>There are several ways to explain the form Łāśīḥ$ in pāda c.
              The easiest is to treat it as a singular accusative neuter.
              Alternatively, it could be a plural accusative feminine from Łāśī$ and
              then Łsuvipulaṁ$ is either to be understood adverbially or as Łsuvipulā$[Łs$].
              Another way to treat Łāśīḥ$ would be to take it as a nominative standing
              for the accusative.</NOTE>

%folioinfo \msM\ 429.jpg upper, f. 20v
<TEXT> sa hovāca pathīkena kim{ }apūrvam{ }ihāgataḥ|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>sa ho°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; aho° \msCb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>pathīkena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; pathīko na \msNc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>That traveller replied: ``Have you never been here?</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I understand Łpathīkena$ as standing for Łpathikena$ metri causa (see 12.64b) and not
              as two words, Łpathī kena$. This means that we are forced to accept an instrumental as the agent 
              of the finite verb Łuvāca$. I suspect that \msNc's reading (Łpathīko$) 
              is an attempt to correct the syntax, but in this way Łapūrvam$ becomes 
              problematic. With Łpūrvam$ tha sentence may mean: `The traveller replied:
                ``Have you not come here before?'' '</NOTE>

<TEXT> dakṣiṇāpathadeśo 'yaṁ naravīrapuraṁ tv{ }adaḥ||</TEXT> 12.60
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°patha°</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; °pathe \msCb</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>°puraṁ tv{ }adaḥ</LEM> \msCb; °puraṁ tv{ }ayaḥ \msCa, °puraṁ tv{ }ayaṁ \msCc\msNa,                                                purandaraḥ \msNc, °puraṁ svayam \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>This is the Deccan region, and this is the city of Naravīra.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Łayam$ as the end of this verse may have been the original reading and
                \msCb\ may have corrected it to Ładaḥ$. Another possibility is that
                an original Ładaḥ$ is preserved in \msCb, and it got corrupted to
                Łayaḥ$ (\msCa), and then to Łayaṁ$ (\msCc\msNa). 
                In any case, I have chosen the reading Ładaḥ$
                because it works better; it can be viewed as my editorial correction.</NOTE>
%index_geo: dakṣiṇāpathadeśa (Deccan)
%index_geo: Naravīrapura

<APP>\vcd <LEM>gandham{ }aho phalaṁ</LEM> \corr; gandham{ }aho phala \msCa\msCbpcorr\msCc\msNa\Ed,                                 gandham{ }aho gandham{ }aho phala \msCbacorr, gandho phalaṁ aho \msNc</APP>

<TEXT> tat{ }phalaṁ na mahījātaṁ na merau na ca mandare|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>tat{ }pha°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; yat{ }pha° \Ed</APP>
<APP>\vb <LEM>merau</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNcpcorr\Ed; mero \msCc\msNcacorr</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>mandare</LEM> \conj; kandare \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc\Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>This fruit was not produced on earth, not even on Mount Meru or ... </TR> -->
        <NOTE>Most probaby, Łkandare$ (`in a cave') in pāda b is an early
                 mistake for Łmandare$ (`on Mount Mandara'), a location that
                 appears frequently in the epics and the Purāṇas next
                 to Mount Meru. This is why I conjecture Łmandare$ here.</NOTE>

<TEXT> devalokika suvyaktaṁ na martya upajāyate||</TEXT> 12.69
<APP>\vd <LEM>martya upajāyate</LEM> \eme; martya<UNCL>mupajā</UNCL>×× \msCa,martya supajāyate \msCb, martyam{ }upajāyate \msCc\msNa\msNc,                                                        mahyām{ }upajāyate \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>It is clearly from the world of gods, [this kind of fruit] does not grow in 
                        the world of humans.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Łdevalokika$ in pāda c as a stem form compound (metri causa) for a more standard
              Łdevalaukikaṁ$.
              Łmartya-m-upajāyate$ in pāda d might be original, with Łm$ as a sandhi bridge. Nevertheless,
              I emended the pāda to make it clearer.</NOTE>

              meaning Łphala$ (see 12.71--72, 108).
              The translation I have chosen is tentative.</NOTE>

<TEXT> na vanena vane rājan{ }na vāṇijyakr̥ṣeṇa vā|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>na vanena</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; na phaledaṁ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>rājan{ }na</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc\Ed; rājānna \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>``Your majesty, one cannot obtain [such a fruit by wondering] from forest to forest. 
                It cannot be obtained through merchants or by cultivating the land.</TR> -->
                <NOTE>  Pāda a could be construed as Łna vane na vane rājan$
                        (`Your majesty, there is no [such fruit] in any
                        forest'), but a similar expression, Łvanena
                        vanaṁ$, occurs e.g. in MBh
                        1.144.1 meaning `from forest to forest' (Łte vanena
                        vanaṁ vīrā ghnanto mr̥gagaṇān bahūn| apakramya yayū
                        rājaṁs tvaramāṇā mahārathāḥ||$), and this made me
                        choose another option (Łna vanena vane rājan$). \Ed's variant
                        seems like an attempt to `correct'
                        the text.
                </NOTE>

% odd syntax
<TEXT> sa phalaṁ dattam{ }evāsi suhr̥datvān{ }mayā tava||</TEXT> 12.108
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°vāsi</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °vā<UNCL>bhi</UNCL> \msNa, °vābhiḥ \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>suhr̥datvān{ }mayā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNc; suhr̥datvāt{ }mayā \msNa, sa ca datvā mayā \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>I gave you that fruit out of my friendship for you.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the odd syntax of pādas cd. Łsa phalaṁ$ may have been influenced 
                by 12.71d and 72a. Here Łtat phalaṁ$ would work
                better but see Łsa phalaṁ$ in a similarly odd position in 
                12.113d. Łdattam evāsi$ is also problematic although similar
                structures do appear in this text, e.g. in 12.113c. The original may have read
                Łtat phalam datta evāsi$; or take Łdattam evāsi$ as Łdatta-m-evāsi$,
                with a hiatus breaker Ł-m-$.</NOTE>
%index_grammar: syntax: aham asmi phalaṁ dattaṁ

<TEXT> anyad{ }dātuṁ na śaknomi gaccha somapurādya vai|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>anyad{ }dā°</LEM> \msNa\msNc\Ed; anya dā° \msCa\msCb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°purādya</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc; °parādya \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>I cannot give you another one. Go now to Soma's city.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Understand Łpurādya$ as Łpuram adya$ (stem form metri causa)</NOTE>
%index_grammar: stem form metri causa (purādya)

<TEXT> itihāsaḥ purāṇaṁ ca sāṁkhya yogaḥ patañjalam||</TEXT> 12.138
        <APP>\vc <LEM>purāṇaṁ ca</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNc; purāṇaś{ }ca \msCb\Ed</APP>
<APP>\vd <LEM>°yogaḥ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; °yoga \msCc</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>°jalam</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; °jali \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>as well as Itihāsa, Purāṇa and Pātañjala Sāṁkhyayoga,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note the form Łpatañjalam$ metri causa for Łpātañjalam$.
                It is difficult to say if Łsāṁkhya yoga$ in pāda d signifies one or two
                things. I have chosen to separate them, interpreting Łsāṁkhya$ as a stem form
                noun, because in other parts of the text, Łsāṁkhya$ and Łyoga$ are usually treated as
                two different traditions. See 8.1--3, 16.36--37, and 23.5c. 
                Understand Łpatañjalam$ as Łpātañjalaḥ$ (metri causa and gender confusion).
                Another, less likely, possibility is that here Łsāṁkhyayoga$ and
                Łpātañjalayoga$ are contrasted.</NOTE>

%index_texts: itihāsa
%index_texts: purāṇa
%index_texts: sāṁkhya
%index_texts: pātañjalayoga

<TEXT> śrutvaivovāca brahmā vipulamati punar{ }mānayitvā yathāvat</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>śrutvaivovāca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNc; śrutvaiva vāca \Ed</APP>
<APP><LEM>°mati</LEM> \msCc\Ed; °matiḥ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\ \unmetr</APP>
<APP><LEM>mānayitvā</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa; māṇayitvā \msNc, mānayaṁvā \Ed</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>yathāvat</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNapcorr\msNc\Ed; vat \msNaacorr</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Hearing [this] Brahmā spoke to [Vipula] of huge intellect, honouring [him] as follows.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>The stem form noun °Łmati$ of the bahuvrīhi compound 
                in pāda a may stand for Łmatiḥ$ (see the unmetrical reading of \msCa\msCb\msNa), and
                then it should refer to Brahmā himself (`Brahmā, the one with a huge intellect...').
                I have choosen to take Łmati$ as a stem form noun standing for the accusative,
                referring to Vipula. This works better because Łmānayitvā$ (and Łśrutvā$) requires an object.</NOTE>

<CHAPTER>pañcadaśamo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>
<!-- <TRCHAPTER>Chapter Fifteen</TRCHAPTER> -->

<SUBCHAPTER>jīvavarṇanam</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The description of the soul</TRSUBCHAPTER>


<TEXT> devy{ }uvāca|*</TEXT>

<TEXT> saṁsārapāraṁ paramaṁ nayasva</TEXT>
<APP>\vd <LEM>paramaṁ</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNc\Ed; parama \msNb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>nayasva</LEM> \msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc\Ed; naya¤ \msCa</APP>

<TEXT> kr̥pāṁ mayīśāna kuru prasīda||</TEXT>
        <APP>\vd <LEM>kr̥pāṁ mayīśāna kuru prasīda</LEM> \Ed; \om\ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\msNc</APP>
        % \vc \om\ \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb
        <NOTE>Pāda c and pāda d are in the reverse order in \Ed and pāda d (Łkr̥pāṁ...$), and while it is
                missing from all the palm-leaf manuscripts, it appears as the last line of this stanza in 
                two paper manuscripts: NGMPP A 1341-6 (NAK 4/93) and NGMPP C 107-7 (Kesar 537). One of these (or both) 
                may have been the main source for Naraharinath's edition. Note also that these
                two paper manuscripts seem to have been written by the same hand.</NOTE>

<CHAPTER>viṁśatimo 'dhyāyaḥ</CHAPTER>

<ANUSTUBH/>
<TEXT> vigatarāga uvāca|*</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Vigatarāga spoke:</TR> -->

% numbers singular!
<TEXT> pañcaviṁśati yat{ }tattvaṁ jñātum{ }icchāmi tattvataḥ|</TEXT>

<TEXT> kathayasva mamādya tvaṁ chidyate yena saṁśayaḥ||</TEXT> 20.1
        <!-- <TR>I would like to learn about the twenty-five Tattvas truely. 
                 Teach me now so that my doubts could be dispelled.</TR> -->
        <NOTE> This chapter echoes and is partly based on MBh 12.247.1-10 (Mokṣadharma, see
                        parallel passages in the apparatus):
                <sep/>
                        Łbhīṣma uvāca |<br/>
                        bhūtānāṁ guṇasaṁkhyānaṁ bhūyaḥ putra niśāmaya |<br/>
                        dvaipāyanamukhād bhraṣṭaṁ ślāghayā parayānagha ||$1<br/>
                        Łdīptānalanibhaḥ prāha bhagavān dhūmravarcase |<br/>
                        tato 'ham api vakṣyāmi bhūyaḥ putra nidarśanam ||$2<br/>
                        Łbhūmeḥ sthairyaṁ pr̥thutvaṁ ca kāṭhinyaṁ prasavātmatā |<br/>
                        gandho gurutvaṁ śaktiś ca saṁghātaḥ sthāpanā dhr̥tiḥ ||$3<br/>
                        Łapāṁ śaityaṁ rasaḥ kledo dravatvaṁ snehasaumyatā |<br/>
                        jihvā viṣyandinī caiva bhaumāpyāsravaṇaṁ tathā ||$4<br/>
                        Łagner durdharṣatā tejas tāpaḥ pākaḥ prakāśanam |<br/>
                        śaucaṁ rāgo laghus taikṣṇyaṁ daśamaṁ cordhvabhāgitā ||$5<br/>
                        Łvāyor aniyamaḥ sparśo vādasthānaṁ svatantratā |<br/>
                        balaṁ śaighryaṁ ca mohaś ca ceṣṭā karmakr̥tā bhavaḥ ||$6<br/>
                        Łākāśasya guṇaḥ śabdo vyāpitvaṁ chidratāpi ca |<br/>
                        anāśrayam anālambam avyaktam avikāritā ||$7<br/>
                        Łapratīghātatā caiva bhūtatvaṁ vikr̥tāni ca |<br/>
                        guṇāḥ pañcāśataṁ proktāḥ pañcabhūtātmabhāvitāḥ ||$8<br/>
                        Łcalopapattir vyaktiś ca visargaḥ kalpanā kṣamā |<br/>
                        sad asac cāśutā caiva manaso nava vai guṇāḥ ||$9<br/>
                        Łiṣṭāniṣṭavikalpaś ca vyavasāyaḥ samādhitā |<br/>
                        saṁśayaḥ pratipattiś ca buddhau pañceha ye guṇāḥ ||$10<br/>
        </NOTE>

<SUBCHAPTER>puruṣaḥ-śivaḥ-brahmā (25)</SUBCHAPTER>
<TRSUBCHAPTER>The Puruṣa/Śiva/Brahmā (25th)</TRSUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> nādimadhyaṁ na cāntaṁ ca yan{ }na vedyaṁ surair{ }api|</TEXT>
<APP>\va <LEM>°madhyaṁ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °madya \msNb</APP>
<APP>                 <LEM>cāntaṁ ca</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; cāntaś{ }ca \Ed</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>surair{ }api</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; surer{ }api \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>That which has no beginning, no middle part and no end, 
                and is not to be known even by the gods,</TR> -->

<TEXT> atisūkṣmo hy{ }atisthūlo nirālambo nirañjanaḥ||</TEXT> 20.3 
        <APP>\vc <LEM>hy{ }ati°</LEM> \msCa\msCb\msNa\msNb\Ed; hy{ }adi° \msCc</APP>
        <!-- <TR>that which is extremely subtle and extremely large, supportless and spotless,</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Note that the key terms (Łādi, madhya, anta, sūkṣma$) in this verse are to be found in VSS 1.1ab:
                <sep/>
               Ł anādimadhyāntam anantapāraṁ<br/>
                 susūkṣmam avyaktajagatsusāram$</NOTE>

<TEXT> acintyaś{ }cāprameyaś{ }ca akṣarākṣaravarjitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>inconceivable, immeasurable, imperishable, devoid of syllables,</TR> -->

<TEXT> sarvaḥ sarvagato vyāpī sarvam{ }āvr̥tya tiṣṭhati||</TEXT> 20.4
        <APP>\vcd <LEM>(sarvaḥŁ...$ tiṣṭhati)</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>that which is everything and everywhere and that which is pervasive, 
                        exists covering everything.</TR> -->

<TEXT> sarvendriyaguṇābhāsaḥ sarvendriyavivarjitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\vab <LEM>sarve°Ł...$ varjitaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; \om\ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>It appears to have the qualities of all the sense faculties
                         but is devoid of all sense faculties.</TR> -->

% -jaḥ is a bit suspicious; I take it as a-jaḥ
<TEXT> ajarāmarajaḥ śāntaḥ paramātmā śivo 'vyayaḥ||</TEXT> 20.5
        <APP>\vc <LEM>°jaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\msNb; yaḥ \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>It is not subject to ageing, it is immortal and unborn. It is peaceful, it is 
                the supreme soul, it is undecaying Śiva.</TR> -->
        <NOTE>I take Łajarāmarajaḥ$ in Łpāda$ a as Łajaro 'maro 'ajaś ca$.</NOTE>

% go for brahma?

        <APP>\vb <LEM>brahmā</LEM> \msCa\msCb\Ed; brahma \msCc\msNa\msNb</APP>

                        it is called Puruṣa.</TR> -->

<TEXT> pañcaviṁśaḥ sa vijñeyo janmamr̥tyuharaḥ prabhuḥ||</TEXT> 20.6
<APP>\vc <LEM>°viṁśaḥ</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNb\Ed; °viṁśat \msNaacorr, °viṁśa \msNapcorr</APP>

        <!-- <TR>It is to be known as the twenty-fifth [Tattva], the Lord (Łprabhu$) who destroys death and rebirth.</TR> -->
% Viṣṇu is not mentioned

<TEXT> kalākalaṅkanirmukto vyomapañcāśavarjitaḥ|</TEXT>
        <APP>\va <LEM>°nirmukto</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °lirmukto \msNb</APP>
        <APP>\vb <LEM>°pañcāśa°</LEM> \mssCaCbCc\msNa\Ed; °pañcasa° \msNb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>He is free of the stain of having parts[?], and is devoid of the fifty voids.</TR> -->

%folioinfo \msM\ 445.jpg lower, f. 38r 
%folioinfo \Ed\ p.656
<TEXT> jalapakṣī yathā toyair{ }na lipyeta jale caran|</TEXT>
<APP>\vcd <LEM>yathā toyair{ }na</LEM> \msCa\Ed; yathā toyī na \msCbacorr,                        yathā toyer{ }na \msCbpcorr, yathā toyai na \msCc\msNa, yadā toyai nna \msNb</APP>

<APP>                 <LEM>jale</LEM> \msCa\msCc\msNa\msNb\Ed; jalai \msCb</APP>
        <!-- <TR>As a waterbird is not stained by the water while swimming in it,</TR> -->

<TEXT> tadvad{ }doṣair{ }na lipyeta pāpakarmaśatair{ }api||</TEXT> 20.7

        <NOTE>Note that from now on in this chapter, Łguṇa$ is used in the sense of the Łtanmātra$ of Sāṁkhya philosophy
        and that the word Łtanmātra$ does not occur in the VSS.</NOTE>

%%MMW  guṇa:
  an attribute of the 5 elements (each of which has its own peculiar quality or qualities as well as organ of sense
  thus 1. ether has śabda, or sound for its Guṇa and the ear for its organ
  2. the air has tangibility and sound for its Guṇas and the skin for its organ
  3. fire or light has shape or colour, tangibility, and sound for its Guṇas, and the eye for its organs
  4. water has flavour, shape, tangibility, and sound for its Guṇas, and the tongue for its organ
  5. earth has the preceding Guṇas, with the addition of its own peculiar Guṇa of smell, and the nose for its organ), Mn. i, 20 and 76-78
  MBh. xii, 6846 ff. [see 12.23.23?]
  Śakuntalā i, 1:
        yā sr̥ṣṭiḥ sraṣṭur ādyā vahati vidhi-hutaṁ yā havir yā ca hotrī
        ye dve kālaṁ vidhattaḥ śruti-viṣaya-guṇā yā sthitā vyāpya viśvam /
        yām āhuḥ sarva-bīja-prakr̥tir iti yayā prāṇinaḥ prāṇavantaḥ
        pratyakṣābhiḥ prapannas tanubhir avatu vas tābhir aṣṭābhir īśaḥ // KSak_1.1 //p.2
  BhP. iii, 5, 35:
        BhP_03.05.035/1 jyotiṣāmbho 'nusaṁsr̥ṣṭaṁ vikurvad brahma-vīkṣitam
        BhP_03.05.035/2 mahīṁ gandha-guṇām ādhāt kāla-māyāṁśa-yogataḥ

Encyclopedia of Indian Philosophies. Vol. 4. Sāṁkhya. ed. Larson and Bhattacharya. p. 121-122:
``V.M. Bedekar has nicely summarized the differences between this sort of fluid Sāṁkhya and Yoga and later 
philosophical Sāṁkhya:
        "(i) In the *Mokṣadharma* Sāṁkhya, there is not always emphasized an absolute and clear-cut dualism as in the classical
        Sāṁkhya. Many of the teachers of the Sāṁkhya in the *Mokṣadharma* appear generrally to posit, at the apex, one single
        Principle or entity which overrides the dualism. (ii) The *Mokṣadharma* Sāṁkhya, often, speaks of the doctrine 
        of the eight Prakr̥tis, as against the one Prakr̥ti of the classical Sāṁkhya. (iii) The doctrine of the *tanmātras*
        (subtle elements) does not seem to have yet developed. There is, however, a mention of the five objects of
        senses or the five qualities of the elements. (iv) The teaching regarding the number, place and functions of the
        phychical faculties like *manas*, *ahaṁkāra*, and *buddhi* does not appear to have been consolidated in the 
        *Mokṣadharma*. Different teachers have expressed different views on the subject. (v) The origin or the source of
        of the five senses of knowledge has not been fixed as in the classical Sāṁkhya."   ''
[See Bedekar. Introduction to the Śāntiparvan. p. ccxliii ]

Larson Classical Sāṁkhya p. 114 on guṇa:
Moreover, in the Moksadharma the term guna is used in
a variety of ways as Edgerton, Johnston and others have noticed.
It frequently appears, of course, in the standard use as "quality"
of the avyakta or prakrti — e.g., XII. 294,32; 293, 33-34.
The term appears also, however, in the sense of "quality" or
"aspect" of the gross elements — e.g., XII 244, 4; 267, 13-15.
Then, too, the term is used in the sense of vikära or
"secondary part" — e.g., XII. 295, 13-17; 267, 28-29. 106

p115
The next two terms — i.e., puru$a and
ätman — seem to be used interchangeably throughout the epic,
and they function both as cosmic and individual conceptions. 113

see also p188
ibid. p.72: "The classical doctrines of *prakr̥ti*, *satkāryovāda*, *tattvavikāra* and the *tanmātras* are 
not present in these early forms of Sāṁkhya."
ibid p73: (j) By the 7th or 8th century A.D., according to Frauwallner, Sāmkhya has seriously declined. After a gap of many
centuries, Sāmkhya has a kind of renaissance as evidenced in
the late Sāṁkhyapravacanasūtra and the work of Vijñānabhikṣu,
Mahādeva and Aniruddha.

p74. (d) Problem of the introduction of tanmātras.

Larson Classical Sāṁkhya p19: Garbe: by no means an older form, no preliminary stage of the "classical," that is, the real, pure Samkhya, but
an unclear, partly pointless mixed philosophy. 66 ; 44ff : Johnston's steps...: 4 (f) the great elements and the objects of the senses
are replaced in these later speculations by the tanmätras and the gross elements — probably because of influence from Vaiksikas.
p50 Frauwallner's stage 2 (no tanmātras yet)!

p188: In the older accounts of the tattvas the five gross elements functioned in place of the
tanmātras, and the remaining five tattvas were the objects of the
senses, which are left out of the classical Sāmkhya listing.

MBh 12
SECTION CCCXXXIX

"Bhishma said, 'Arrived at the spacious realm called White Island, the illustrious Rishi beheld
those same white men possessed of lunar splendour (of whom I have already spoken to thee).
Worshipped by them, the Rishi worshipped them in return by bending his head and reverencing them in
his mind. 1 Desirous of beholding Narayana, he began to reside there, attentively engaged in the
silent recitation of mantras, sacred to him, and observant of vows of the most difficult kind, with
concentrated mind, the regenerate Rishi, with arms upraised, stood in Yoga, and then sang the
following hymn unto the Lord of the universe, Him, viz., who is at once the soul of attributes and
divested of all attributes.

SECTION CCCXL

"Bhishma said, 'Thus hymned with names that were not known to others, the Divine Narayana having the
universe for his form showed himself to the ascetic Narada. His form was somewhat purer than the
moon and differed from the moon in some respects. He somewhat resembled a blazing fire in
complexion. The puissant Lord was somewhat of the form of Vishti. 1 He resembled in some respects
the feathers of the parrot, and in some a mass of pure crystal.

        % Flo Dharmasūtras 5 yajñas and their "explanations" check, see also ŚDU lists 
        % BhG chs. 3 and 4.27--28 already yoga is yajña Nirajan
        % dravyayaj~
% mahāyajña in Manu, ŚDhU(?) 1 and 3
Kenji in his article:
According to the classical formulation, the five mahāyajñas are bhūtayajña, manuṣyayajña, pitr̥yajña, devayajña, and brahmayajña, which are defined as giving oblation to spirits, worshipping of guests, the libation for ancestors, homa sacrifice, and the learning of Veda. (cf. Śatapathabrāhmaṇa 11.5.6.1–3, Mānavadharmaśāstra 3.68–70). We can observe that ŚDh-UMS 1.56 has agniyajña instead of manuṣyayajña. agniyajña can stand for Agnihotra. One could also argue that manuṣyatā in pāda d is somehow intended as a reference to manuṣyayajña. Mānavadharmaśāstra 4.21 has slightly different members of mahāyajñas: r̥ṣiyajña, devayajña, bhūtayajña, nr̥yajña, pitr̥yajña replacing brahmayajña with r̥ṣiyajña.

9.33 
Sentence: a    mitro návākṣareṇa trivŕ̥tam̐ stómam úd ajayat tám új jeṣam \
Sentence: b    varuṇo dáśākṣareṇa virā́jam úd ajayat tā́m új jeṣam \
Sentence: c    índra ekā́daśākṣareṇa triṣṭúbʰam úd ajayat tā́m új jeṣam \
Sentence: d    víśve devā́ dvā́daśākṣareṇa jágatīm úd ajayam̐s tā́m új jeṣam \\

daśākṣareṇa mantreṇa ye pibanti jalaṁ narāḥ  // RKV_49.38 //
Śāradatilaka:
humādir eṣaḥ kathito rāmamantro daśākṣaraḥ || 101 ||

<SUBCHAPTER>sapta dvīpāḥ priyavratasutāś{ }ca</SUBCHAPTER>

<TEXT> sapta dvīpās{ }tato jñeyāḥ saptasāgarasaṁvr̥tāḥ|</TEXT>
        <!-- <TR>Then one should learn about the seven islands, which 
             are surrounded by seven oceans.</TR> -->
       <NOTE>See VSS 4.12 for a reference to the myth of Priyavrata dividing the earth into seven parts,
                thus producing the seven seas and the seven islands.</NOTE>

                see, e.g., Vāyupurāṇa 33.1 ff.$</PARAL>

% CHECK \msCb
<TEXT> śivakṣemo dhruvaś{ }caiva sapta medhātitheḥ sutāḥ||</TEXT> 24.27
        <APP>\vc <LEM>śiva°</LEM> \msCa; śivaśiva° \Ed</APP>
        <!-- <TR>Śiva, Kṣema and Dhruva: these are Medhātithi's seven sons 
             [and the names of their countries].</TR> -->
        <NOTE>Purāṇic Encyclopedia p. 499
        ( https://www.sanskrit-lexicon.uni-koeln.de/scans/PEScan/2020/web/webtc/servepdf.php?page=499-b ):
                                ``MEDHĀTITHI I . Grandson of Svāyambhuva Manu.
                                Svāyambhuva Manu had two sons named Priyavrata and
                                Uttānapāda. Of these Priyavrata married Sarūpā and
                                Barhiṣmatī, daughters of Viśvakarmaprajāpati. Medhā-
                                tithi was the son born to Priyavrata of Sarūpā. Agnī-
                                dhra, and others were the brothers of Medhātithi.
                                Medhātithi became the King of Plakṣadvīpa after the
                                death of Priyavrata. (8th Skandha, Devī Bhāgavata).
                                Medhātithi got seven sons named Śāntahaya, Śiśira,
                                Sukhodaya, Ānanda, Śiva. Kṣemaka and Dhruva. They
                                all became Kings of Plakṣadvīpa. The countries they
                                ruled were named after them as Śāntahayavarṣa, Śiśira-
                                varṣa, Sukhodayavarṣa, Ānandavarṣa, Śivavarṣa, Kṣema-
                                kavarṣa and Dhruvavarṣa. There are seven mountains
                                showing the boundaries of these states and they are
                                called Gomeda, Cāndra, Nārada, Dundubhi, Somaka,
                                Sumana and Vaibhrāja. In these beautiful countries
                                and grand mountains live a great many Devas,
                                Gandharvas and virtuous men. (Chapter 4, Aṁśa 2,
                                Viṣṇu Purāṇa).''</NOTE>
